SaPL Plenary Session, Plenary Room Add to My Program
[keynote III] Machine Learning Methods for Real-Time Robot Control with
Theoretical Guarantees
SaAT2 Special Session, Room T2 Add to My Program
Novel Planning and Control Approaches for Semiconductor Manufacturing I
Chair: Moench, Lars University of Hagen
Organizer: Moench, Lars University of Hagen
Organizer: Yugma, Claude Ecole Des Mines De Saint-Etienne
10:00-10:15, Paper SaAT2.1 Add to My Program
Data-Driven Strategies for Optimizing Lot Priority Allocation to Reduce Cycle Times in Semiconductor Manufacturing (I)
Wartelle, Adrien Mines Saint-Etienne
Dauzere-Peres, Stephane Mines Saint-Etienne
Yugma, Claude Ecole Des Mines De Saint-Etienne
Christ, Quentin STMicroelectronics Crolles
Roussel, Renaud STMicroelectronics Crolles
Keywords: Semiconductor Manufacturing , Planning, Scheduling and Coordination , Logistics
Abstract: Semiconductor manufacturing companies with a large portfolio of products (``high-mix'') have to manage lots with different levels of urgency in their factories, and thus with multiple priority classes. This study aims to characterize the impact of the percentage of lots in each priority class (``priority mix'') on their cycle times. A data-driven model is introduced that predicts the impact of a given priority mix on the cycle times of lots in each priority class. Through both simulation and analytical modeling approaches, a numerical study on industrial data shows a 0.17% change in cycle time per 1% increase of the ratio of ``hot'' priority jobs. We believe that the key methodological and modeling contributions of this study are important to improve priority mix management, which is critical in semiconductor manufacturing.
10:15-10:30, Paper SaAT2.2 Add to My Program
Comparing Dispatching Rules for Minimizing the Total Weighted Tardiness in the Cleaning-Diffusion Manufacturing Stage (I)
Corsini, Roberto Rosario University of Catania
Costa, Antonio University of Catania
Oriti, Giuseppe University of Catania
Fichera, Sergio University of Catania
Vinciguerra, Daniele STMicroelectronics
Scroppo, Marco Stefano STMicroelectronics
Pagano, Daniele STMicroelectronics
Keywords: Semiconductor Manufacturing , Planning, Scheduling and Coordination
Abstract: This research is motivated by a dynamic dispatching and batching problem within the cleaning-diffusion work area of a semiconductor manufacturing company located in the Southern Italy. Among various work areas in semiconductor manufacturing systems, the cleaning-diffusion area stands out as one of the most critical and complex stage due to long processing times and numerous constraints. Unlike existing literature, we model the cleaning-diffusion work area as a two-stage reentrant hybrid flow shop, including all realistic constraints derived from the case study, such as waiting time constraints and machine preloading. We conduct a comprehensive comparison among several heuristic rules, including some variants of the Apparent Tardiness Cost and Batch Apparent Tardiness Cost, based on industrial instances coming from the literature. Various scenarios involving arrival times and due dates are considered, and the analysis of results delineates the best-performing combinations of dispatching and batching policies in terms of total weighted tardiness.
SaAT3 Special Session, Room T3 Add to My Program
Machine Learning for Optimization in Automation I
Co-Chair: Fanti, Maria Pia Politecnico Di Bari
Organizer: Jia, Qing-Shan Tsinghua University
Organizer: Yan, Bing Rochester Institute of Technology
Organizer: Lennartson, Bengt Chalmers University of Technology
Organizer: Fanti, Maria Pia Politecnico Di Bari
10:00-10:15, Paper SaAT3.1 Add to My Program
A Survey of Reinforcement Learning for Optimization in Automation (I)
Farooq, Ahmad University of Arkansas at Little Rock
Iqbal, Kamran University of Arkansas at Little Rock
Keywords: Reinforcement , Deep Learning in Robotics and Automation , Planning, Scheduling and Coordination
Abstract: Reinforcement Learning (RL) has become a critical tool for optimization challenges within automation, leading to significant advancements in several areas. This review article examines the present landscape of RL within automation, with a particular focus on its roles in manufacturing, energy systems, and robotics. It delves into state-of-the-art methods, major challenges, and upcoming avenues of research within each sector, highlighting RL's capacity to solve intricate optimization challenges. The paper reviews the advantages and constraints of RL-driven optimization methods in automation. It points out prevalent challenges encountered in RL optimization, including issues related to sample efficiency and scalability; safety and robustness; interpretability and trustworthiness; transfer learning and meta-learning; and real-world deployment and integration. It further explores prospective strategies and future research pathways to navigate these challenges. Additionally, the survey includes an comprehensive list of relevant research papers, making it an indispensable guide for scholars and practitioners keen on exploring this domain.
10:15-10:30, Paper SaAT3.2 Add to My Program
Offline Contextual Learning with Correlated Bayesian Beliefs (I)
Zhang, Fan Chinese Academy of Sciences
Gao, Siyang City University of Hong Kong
Song, Jie Peking University
Keywords: Optimization and Optimal Control , Simulation and Animation , Machine learning
Abstract: In this work, we investigate the offline contextual learning in simulation optimization. In offline contextual learning, the optimal design changes with the context. Therefore, the optimal design needs to be carefully determined for each possible context. Existing research has paid little attention to the impact of correlations between different designs' performances on the efficiency of offline contextual learning. In this study, we consider the Bayesian framework and utilize a multi-output Gaussian process to capture correlations between different designs' performances. We verify that considering correlations can accelerate the decay of posterior variance. Taking the KG-type strategy as an example, we construct a new Bayesian sampling policy, CIKG. Finally, we show the effectiveness of CIKG through numerical experiments.
10:30-10:45, Paper SaAT3.3 Add to My Program
MILP Models for Flexible Job Shop Scheduling with Spatial Constraints and Sequence Flexibility (I)
Han, Yunjun Institute of Automation, Chinese Academy of Sciences
Peng, Shaoming Institute of Automation, Chinese Academy of Sciences
Shen, Zhen Institute of Automation, Chinese Academy of Sciences
Tao, Zhikun Institute of Automation, Chinese Academy of Sciences
Xiong, Gang Institute of Automation, Chinese Academy of Sciences
Keywords: Planning, Scheduling and Coordination
Abstract: Within the evolving landscape of Industry 4.0, the significance of flexible job shop scheduling problems is on the rise. This study addresses a novel category of NP-hard scheduling problems: the flexible job shop scheduling problems that incorporate site routing and operation sequencing flexibility. These problems are crucial and applicable in various contexts, including carrier-based aircraft scheduling, shipbuilding assembly scheduling, and cutting tool operation scheduling. For these problems, we present two new MILP models: Model-1 is a time-indexed model, and Model-2 is a precedence variable-based model. These models are evaluated under ten cases of the problems. Our findings indicate that the two models exhibit varying solution efficiencies when dealing with problems of diverse magnitudes. Model-2 performs better than Model-1 on small-scale problems, while Model-1 outperforms Model-2 on medium-scale problems.
10:45-11:00, Paper SaAT3.4 Add to My Program
Optimization of Embedded System with Edge Computing and Sleep Modes for Balance between Energy Consumption and Cache Occupancy (I)
Hou, Chen Peking University
Keywords: Optimization and Optimal Control , Cyber-physical Production Systems and Industry 4.0 , Embedded Systems in Meso, Micro and Nano Scale
Abstract: The paper considers the embedded system that can either compute tasks locally by itself or offload tasks to the edge server for remote computing during the running period (RP) and switch to the sleep mode to save energy once the RP ends. The tasks are stored in the cache, and the more tasks are computed during the RP, the less cache space will be occupied at the end of RP, while also leading to more energy consumption. Meanwhile, the sleep mode that the embedded system enters during the IP also influences the energy consumption. Therefore, how to make the optimal tradeoff between energy consumption and cache occupancy arises as an interesting and challenging issue. To address this issue, this paper first establishes an optimization-theoretical framework to formulate the energy consumption under the constraint of cache occupancy and then proposes an algorithm to minimize the energy consumption within the acceptable level of cache occupancy. Field experiments jointly verify its performance.
SaAT4 Special Session, Room T4 Add to My Program
Autonomous Systems for Agriculture and Horticulture I
Chair: Anisi, David A. ABB
Co-Chair: Lim, Shen Hin University of Waikato
Organizer: Anisi, David A. NMBU
Organizer: Lim, Shen Hin University of Waikato
Organizer: Duke, Mike Waikato University
Organizer: McGuinness, Benjamin John University of Waikato
Organizer: Khaksar, Weria Norwegian University of Life Sciences
Organizer: Candea Leite, Antonio Norwegian University of Life Sciences
Organizer: A. Hameed, Ibrahim NTNU I Ã…lesund
10:00-10:15, Paper SaAT4.1 Add to My Program
Safety Assurance of Autonomous Agricultural Robots: From Offline Model-Checking to Runtime Verification (I)
Adam, Mustafa Norwegian University of Life Sciences
Hartmark, Elias Norwegian University of Life Sciences
Andersen, Tage Norwegian University of Life Sciences (NMBU)
Anisi, David A. ABB
Cavalcanti, Ana University of York
Keywords: Formal Methods in Robotics and Automation , Agricultural Automation , Failure Detection and Recovery
Abstract: The ongoing efforts to deploy safety-critical autonomous robots that operate in semi-structured, dynamic, and uncertain environments, reinforce the importance of supplementing traditional risk-management activities, input-based testing, and quality assurance procedures, with formal verification methods. With this approach, one may guarantee safe behavior in all relevant scenarios. In this paper, we propose a safety assurance framework enabling the integrated use of formal verification at all stages of the engineering life-cycle, beginning at the concept study, design, development, deployment, and operation. Along the way, a real use case from the agricultural industry, namely robotic ultra-violet (UVC) plant treatment, is used to demonstrate the proposed methodology. In particular, the transfer of offline model-checking artifacts to Runtime Verification elucidates how safety requirements can be conceptualized and subsequently translated into online monitors that are integrated seamlessly with the robotâ€™s control system. Our study elaborates on the modeling and verification process, and on the accompanying monitoring tool chain that facilitates the integration in ROS2 applications.
10:15-10:30, Paper SaAT4.2 Add to My Program
Robot-Assisted Fruit Harvesting: A Real-World Usability Study (I)
Guevara, Leonardo University of Lincoln
Wariyapperuma, Prabuddhi University of Lincoln
Arunachalam, Hariharan University of Lincoln
Vasconez, Juan Escuela PolitÃ©cnica Nacional
Hanheide, Marc University of Lincoln
Sklar, Elizabeth I. University of Lincoln
Keywords: Agricultural Automation , Human-Centered Automation , Human Factors and Human-in-the-Loop
Abstract: The introduction of mobile robots to assist pickers in transporting crops during fruit harvesting operations is a promising solution to mitigate the impacts of the current labour shortage. However, having robots sharing the workspace with humans involves solving new challenges related to Human-Robot Interaction (HRI). For instance, effective Human-Robot Communication (HRC) methods will be crucial to not only ensure safe and efficient HRI but to mitigate the potential stress of pickers who interact with robots for the first time. If the stress or discomfort levels are not mitigated, then instead of facilitating the harvesting task, the robot can become a burden. In this context, this paper revP{contributes to} one of the first user studies investigating the preferences and requirements of end users (actual pickers) to improve the usability of Robot-Assisted Fruit Harvesting (RAFH) solutions. The study involves real-world experiments and the usability assessment of existing and potential future technology which results and lessons learned can be used as guidelines for agri-robotics companies and stakeholders on how to design and deploy their own RAFH solutions.
10:30-10:45, Paper SaAT4.3 Add to My Program
DAVIS-Ag: A Synthetic Plant Dataset for Prototyping Domain-Inspired Active Vision in Agricultural Robots (I)
Choi, Taeyeong Kennesaw State University
Guevara, Dario University of California Davis
Cheng, Zifei University of California, Davis
Bandodkar, Grisha University of California at Davis
Wang, Chonghan University of California, Davis
Bailey, Brian University of California, Davis
Earles, J. Mason University of California, Davis
Liu, Xin University of California, Davis
Keywords: Agricultural Automation , Computer Vision in Automation , Simulation and Animation
Abstract: In agricultural environments, viewpoint planning can be a critical functionality for a robot with visual sensors to obtain informative observations of objects of interest (e.g., fruits) from complex structures of plant with random occlusions. Although recent studies on active vision have shown some potential for agricultural tasks, each model has been designed and validated on a unique environment that would not easily be replicated for benchmarking novel methods being developed later. In this paper, we introduce a dataset, so-called DAVIS-Ag, for promoting more extensive research on Domain-inspired Active VISion in Agriculture. To be specific, we leveraged our open-source â€œAgMLâ€ framework and 3D plant simulator of â€œHeliosâ€ to produce 502K RGB images from 30K densely sampled spatial locations in 632 synthetic orchards. Moreover, plant environments of strawberries, tomatoes, and grapes are considered at two different scales (i.e., Single-Plant and Multi-Plant). Useful labels are also provided for each image, including (1) bounding boxes and (2) instance segmentation masks for all identifiable fruits, and also (3) pointers to other images of the viewpoints that are reachable by an execution of action so as to simulate active viewpoint selections at each time step. Using DAVIS-Ag, we visualize motivating examples where fruit visibility can dramatically change depending on the pose of the camera view primarily due to occlusions by other components, such as leaves. Furthermore, we present several baseline models with experiment results for benchmarking in the task of target visibility maximization. Transferability to real strawberry environments is also investigated to demonstrate the feasibility of using the dataset for prototyping real-world solutions.
10:45-11:00, Paper SaAT4.4 Add to My Program
AGRIDS: An Advanced Multi-Modal Mapping Architecture for Robotics and Agriculture (I)
Cox, Jonathan University of Lincoln
Hanheide, Marc University of Lincoln
Polvara, Riccardo University of Lincoln
Keywords: Agricultural Automation , Domain-specific Software and Software Engineering
Abstract: In this paper, we address the lack of standardisation in mapping and data storage in robotics and agriculture, aiming to effectively represent and store spatial, semantic, and temporal data for both applications. We propose a novel approach that integrates data from various sources, such as robotic and static sensors, to create comprehensive maps crucial for precision agriculture. Our architecture bridges the gap between robotics and agriculture domains, managing the storage of robotics sensor data and structured data. We combine technologies from context brokers, databases and object storage to integrate multi-modal data to enable more context-aware decision-making, paving the way for advancements in robotics and precision agriculture. Our proposed framework is open-source and available on our repository.
SaAT5 Special Session, Room T5 Add to My Program
AI Enabled Discrete Event Dynamic Systems I
Chair: Zhao, Qianchuan Tsinghua University
Co-Chair: Xia, Li Sun Yat-Sen University
Organizer: Zhao, Qianchuan Tsinghua University
Organizer: Cai, Kai Osaka Metropolitan University
Organizer: Yin, Xiang Shanghai Jiao Tong Univ
Organizer: Xia, Li Sun Yat-Sen University
10:00-10:15, Paper SaAT5.1 Add to My Program
Marking Diagnosability Enforcement of Labeled Petri Nets in the Presence of Sensor Attacks (I)
Yu, Zhenhua Xi'an University of Science and Technology
Qi, Yinyin Xi'an University of Science and Technology
Cong, Xuya Xi'an University of Science and Technology
Keywords: Discrete Event Dynamic Automation Systems , Petri Nets for Automation Control , Failure Detection and Recovery
Abstract: The marking diagnosability of discrete event systems is critical to the security of the systems. Sensor attacks may modify sensor readings in the sensor communication channels, disguising an event that has already occurred as another event, which makes fake observations or loss of observations. In this paper, the marking diagnosability enforcement problem in labeled Petri nets under sensor attacks is studied. First, we define the marking diagnosability of a plant vulnerable to sensor attacks. In order to verify the marking diagnosabilty under sensor attacks, a structure called attacked verifier is proposed. Finally, for a plant that is marking nondiagnosable under sensor attacks, we design a new labeling function to enforce the marking diagnosability based on its attacked verifier.
10:15-10:30, Paper SaAT5.2 Add to My Program
Activation Control of Multiple Piecewise Linear Neural Networks (I)
Hou, Chen Peking University
Keywords: Optimization and Optimal Control , Probability and Statistical Methods , Cyber-physical Production Systems and Industry 4.0
Abstract: Piecewise linear neural networks (PLNNs) are proven universal approximators for continuous functions on the compact domain. For multiple PLNNs (mPLNNs) differing from each other in suffering different approximation errors (AEs) when approximating the same continuous function, activating all the PLNNs to approximate the continuous function, and then, picking up the minimum AE (MAE) from all the AEs seems to be a practical way to arrive at such MAE. Activating PLNNs has to consume energy, and more activated PLNNs provide more AEs to consider, which can maximize the probability of guaranteeing the MAE, while also needing to harvest more energy. Therefore, how to make the optimal tradeoff between energy harvested and approximation accuracy for mPLNNs arises as an interesting issue. To address this problem, this paper first deduces the objective function, with the accumulative probability of obtaining the MAE as the objective and the accumulative energy harvested as the constraint, then proposes an algorithm for mPLNNs to enjoy the maximum probability of achieving the MAE within the acceptable level of accumulative energy harvested. Experiments verify its performance.
10:30-10:45, Paper SaAT5.3 Add to My Program
Self-Triggered Model Predictive Control for Signal Temporal Logic Tasks (I)
Huang, Junyue Shanghai Jiao Tong University
Wang, Chuwei Shanghai Jiao Tong University
Yu, Xinyi University of Southern California
Yin, Xiang Shanghai Jiao Tong Univ
Keywords: Discrete Event Dynamic Automation Systems , Formal Methods in Robotics and Automation
Abstract: In this paper, we investigate the reactive control synthesis problem for discrete-time dynamic systems under signal temporal logic (STL) specifications. Our focus is on addressing this problem within the model predictive control (MPC) framework, which involves iteratively solving optimization problems at each time instant. Traditional MPC controllers for STL tasks necessitate sampling the system state at every time instant. To mitigate sensing costs and conserve communication bandwidth during sensor measurement transmission, we introduce a novel concept termed self-triggered MPC for STL tasks. This self-triggered MPC autonomously determines the optimal state sampling instant dynamically based on the current system state. Our proposed approach aims to reduce the overall sampling rate of the system, resulting in considerable energy savings. We provide case studies to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm.
10:45-11:00, Paper SaAT5.4 Add to My Program
Multi-Agent Path Planning for Finite Horizon Tasks with Counting Time Temporal Logics (I)
Lv, Peng Shanghai Jiaotong University
Li, Shaoyuan Shanghai Jiao Tong University
Yin, Xiang Shanghai Jiao Tong Univ
Keywords: Discrete Event Dynamic Automation Systems , Formal Methods in Robotics and Automation , Motion and Path Planning
Abstract: In this paper, we consider the multi-agent path planning problem for high-level tasks with finite horizons. In many situations, there is the need to count how many times a sub-task is satisfied in order to achieve the overall task. However, existing temporal logic languages, such as linear temporal logic, may not be efficient in describing such requirements. To address this issue, we propose a new temporal logic language called Counting Time Temporal Logic (CTTL) that extends linear temporal logic by explicitly counting the number of times that some tasks are satisfied. To solve the CTTL path planning problem, we use integer linear programming to encode the satisfaction of the task. We demonstrate that our approach is both sound and complete. To validate our results, we present numerical experiments to show the scalability of the proposed approach. Furthermore, we provide a simulation case study of a team of autonomous robots to illustrate the synthesis procedure
SaAT6 Special Session, Room T6 Add to My Program
Cyber-Physical Manufacturing for Small Batch Customization: Challenges,
Enabling Technologies, and Methodologies I
Chair: Li, Ming The Hong Kong Polytechnic University
Co-Chair: Li, Mingxing Jinan University
Organizer: Li, Ming The Hong Kong Polytechnic University
Organizer: Li, Mingxing Jinan University
Organizer: Zhao, Zhiheng The Hong Kong Polytechnic University
Organizer: Chen, Qiqi The Hong Kong Polytechnic University
Organizer: Huang, George Q. The University of Hong Kong
10:00-10:15, Paper SaAT6.1 Add to My Program
Protocol Model and Execution Protocols for Networked MRO Intralogistics (I)
Chen, Qiqi The Hong Kong Polytechnic University
Zhao, Zhiheng The Hong Kong Polytechnic University
Huang, George Q. The University of Hong Kong
Keywords: Cyber-physical Production Systems and Industry 4.0 , Manufacturing, Maintenance and Supply Chains
Abstract: Aviation maintenance, repair, and overhaul intralogistics (MRO intralogistics) are essential for normal aircraft maintenance operations. However, MRO intralogistics faces several challenges, including planning inaccuracy, scheduling disruption, and execution uncertainties. In analogy to computer networking, this study proposes a networked framework for MRO intralogistics management. First, this work designs a protocol model to organize the planning, scheduling, and execution decisions systematically to achieve end-to-end communication among various participants. Second, this study proposes a network topology for organizing the physical logistics elements, such as parts, workers, and logistics equipment. Additionally, the study designs tables to instruct the physical logistics elements quickly. Third, the work designs the execution protocols to address the execution uncertainties in MRO intralogistics, such as absent workers and shortage of equipment. The protocol model and execution protocols of the networked MRO intralogistics realize its flexible and efficient management.
10:15-10:30, Paper SaAT6.2 Add to My Program
Automated Printing Primitive Extraction and Learning for Complexity Reduction in Additive Manufacturing Operations
Lin, Weizhi University of Southern California
Wang, Yuanxiang Tongji University
Huang, Qiang University of Southern California
Keywords: Probability and Statistical Methods , Additive Manufacturing , Model Learning for Control
Abstract: Geometric features have been widely adopted in design and manufacturing to reduce the complexity of freeform product representation and fabrication. In additive manufacturing (AM), however, geometric feature specification is practically inefficient due to infinite product variety and design complexity. Furthermore, identical geometric features can exhibit different quality patterns in AM due to covariate effects such as location difference. To reduce the complexity of AM operations, the printing primitive concept has recently been proposed to represent AM products in a low dimensional space. This work develops a printing primitive extraction approach through a changepoint detection formulation. Using 2D shapes as an illustration, each layer geometry in AM will be represented by finite 2D primitives including curve segments and corners, capturing smooth and non-smooth deviation patterns, respectively. These primitives are automatically extracted from any 2D freeform shape via a changepoint detection algorithm. To demonstrate its application in quality control, a cookie-cutter learning framework is extended to learn and predict the quality of 2D freeform shapes using printing primitives with covariates of size, curvature, and location. Experiments have shown that the complexity of quality prediction in AM can be reduced through the printing primitive method by using only a limited number of training prints.
10:30-10:45, Paper SaAT6.3 Add to My Program
Multi-Model Based Additive Manufacturing: A Framework for Automated Large-Scale 3D Concrete Printing with Industrial Robots
Lachmayer, Lukas Leibniz University Hannover, Insitute of Assembly Technolog
Raatz, Annika Leibniz UniversitÃ¤t Hannover
Recker, Tobias Leibniz University Hanover
Keywords: Automation in Construction , Process Control , Control Architectures and Programming
Abstract: With the advent of additive manufacturing in construction (AMC), new challenges arise in planning, automation and control. Firstly, a majority of manufactured building components are single-walled elements such as walls. This requires explicit print path planning with a wall thickness equal to a single layer width. This contrasts common design rules for additive manufacturing processes and breaks most commercial slicing algorithms. Aside from wall thickness equal to one, the printing material - usually fresh concrete, mortar or earth has a time-dependent compressive strength while curing. This time-dependent material behaviour must be taken into account during print path design to prevent excessive compression loads and ensure component stability for unsupervised printing. Finally, there is a significant challenge emerging from the required component size. Concrete components on a building scale require correspondingly large or even mobile on-site printing systems. Therefore, variable environmental influences affect the material behaviour during the printing process, leading to deviations between as-planned and as-built layers. This publication presents a framework tackling the three challenges of print path planning for components with small wall thicknesses, consideration of time-dependent material behaviour and compensation of external influences. The framework extends state-of-the-art print path planning and printing control approaches to enable automatized robotic additive manufacturing processes in construction. We contribute a path planning algorithm for the 2.5D and 3D production of single-walled components, algorithmic coupling of path planning and FEM simulation to ensure component stability, and an online control approach to compensate for disturbances.
10:45-11:00, Paper SaAT6.4 Add to My Program
Digital Twin-Based Synchronized Decision-Making and Control Method for Kitchen Waste Collection and Transportation System (I)
Wan, Ming Jinan University
Qu, Ting Jinan University
Huang, Manna Jinan University
Sun, Xiaoguang Jinan University
Li, Mingxing Jinan University
Huang, George Q. The University of Hong Kong
Keywords: Cyber-physical Production Systems and Industry 4.0 , Logistics , Process Control
Abstract: Kitchen waste refers to food waste generated by hotels, restaurants, households, canteensï¼Œ and enterprises. If it is not collected and transported in time, it will lead to serious environmental pollution. Therefore, the management of kitchen waste collection and transportation has always been the focus of attention of government departments. However, due to changes in the amount of waste generated, the failure of transfer facilities, traffic congestion and other random dynamic interference, the stable and efficient operation of the collection and transportation system faces challenges. In this paper, a novel digital twin-based synchronized control information architecture and a set of dynamic disturbance-oriented synchronized control mechanisms, models and algorithms are proposed for the kitchen waste recycling and transfer transportation model, aiming at the real-time synchronized operation of the two phases of collection and transportation. Case results confirm the effectiveness of the proposed solution.
SaAT7 Special Session, Room T7 Add to My Program
Collaborative Robot-Enabled Advanced Manufacturing in the Context of
Industry 5.0 I
Chair: Wang, Weitian Montclair State University
Co-Chair: Guo, Xiwang Liaoning Petrochemical University
Organizer: Wang, Weitian Montclair State University
Organizer: Guo, Xiwang Liaoning Petrochemical University
Organizer: Zhou, MengChu New Jersey Institute of Technology
10:00-10:15, Paper SaAT7.1 Add to My Program
Design of Wire-Driven Modular Robot Hand to Handle Daily Objects (I)
Ahn, Jeongdo Korea Institute of Machinery and Materials
Lee, Joonho Korea Institute of Machinery & Materials (kimm)
Park, Jongwoo Korea Institue of Machinery & Materials
Park, Dongil Korea Institute of Machinery and Materials (KIMM)
Park, Chanhun KIMM
Keywords: Tendon/Wire Mechanism , Collaborative Robots in Manufacturing , Industrial and Service Robotics
Abstract: It is very essential for humanoid robots to freely use daily objects. The end effector of a humanoid, or robot hand, should be safe and at the same time have sufficient force to handle daily objects. However, there is a trade-off between the robot hand being safe and producing large force, and it is especially difficult to modularize and integrate the actuator into the robot hand. To address this issue, we propose a wire-driven modular robot hand. In order to absorb external impact, a finger joint was developed using both a flexible wire to flex the finger and an elastic band to straighten the finger. To generate a large force in the direction of grasping an object, pin joints were used in finger joints. The developed robot hand is similar in size to an adult hand (200 mm), weighs 0.4 kg, and can produce a fingertip force of about 10 N per finger. Additionally, there is an advantage in modularity because the actuator for driving the fingers is located in the palm. Finally, we confirmed that the proposed robot hand can handle the daily objects with power grip and precision grip.
10:15-10:30, Paper SaAT7.2 Add to My Program
Enhancing Human-Robot Collaborative Assembly in Manufacturing Systems Using Large Language Models (I)
Lim, Jonghan Pennsylvania State University
Patel, Sujani Pennsylvania State University
Evans, Alexander Pennsylvania State University
Pimley, John Pennsylvania State University
Li, Yifei The Pennsylvania State University
Kovalenko, Ilya Pennsylvania State University
Keywords: Collaborative Robots in Manufacturing , Assembly , AI-Based Methods
Abstract: The development of human-robot collaboration has the ability to improve manufacturing system performance by leveraging the unique strengths of both humans and robots. On the shop floor, human operators contribute with their adaptability and flexibility in dynamic situations, while robots provide precision and the ability to perform repetitive tasks. However, the communication gap between human operators and robots limits the collaboration and coordination of human-robot teams in manufacturing systems. Our research presents a human-robot collaborative assembly framework that utilizes a large language model for enhancing communication in manufacturing environments. The framework facilitates human-robot communication by integrating voice commands through natural language for task management. A case study for an assembly task demonstrates the framework's ability to process natural language inputs and address real-time assembly challenges, emphasizing adaptability to language variation and efficiency in error resolution. The results suggest that large language models have the potential to improve human-robot interaction for collaborative manufacturing assembly applications.
10:30-10:45, Paper SaAT7.3 Add to My Program
A Control Architecture for Safe Trajectory Generation in Humanâ€“Robot Collaborative Settings (I)
Palmieri, Jozsef University of Cassino and Southern Lazio
Di Lillo, Paolo University of Cassino and Southern Lazio
Lippi, Martina University of Roma Tre
Chiaverini, Stefano UniversitÃ  Di Cassino E Del Lazio Meridionale
Marino, Alessandro University of Cassino and Southern Lazio
Keywords: Collision Avoidance , Motion Control , Reactive and Sensor-Based Planning
Abstract: This paper introduces a control architecture that enables a robotic system to ensure the safety of human operators entering its workspace. The proposed method utilizes an appropriate metric to measure safety levels and adjusts the robotâ€™s motion to maintain this metric above a minimum threshold. To guarantee safety, the robot scales down and deviates from its intended path. For redundant robots, internal motion is exploited to enhance safety levels further. The approach is incorporated into a Hierarchical Quadratic Programming control framework, allowing the robot to address other control objectives simultaneously, such as handling joint limits. Experimental results with a dual-arm mobile robot developed as part of the EU-funded CANOPIES project demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method. Note to Practitioners â€”This paper was motivated by the problem of ensuring human safety in unstructured environments shared with human operators. We propose a control architecture that allows complex dual-arm robotic systems to operate effectively in such scenarios. The devised architecture gives the robot the capability to slow down a trajectory to follow as well as to deviate from a nominal path to keep a human operator safe. We tested the devised approach in a precision farming setting; however, it can be adopted in any human-robot interaction scenario.
10:45-11:00, Paper SaAT7.4 Add to My Program
A Passivity-Based Variable Impedance Controller for Incremental Learning of Periodic Interactive Tasks (I)
Dalle Vedove, Matteo University of Trento
Lamon, Edoardo University of Trento
Fontanelli, Daniele University of Trento
Palopoli, Luigi University of Trento
Saveriano, Matteo University of Trento
Keywords: Intelligent and Flexible Manufacturing , Compliance and Impedance Control , Learning and Adaptive Systems
Abstract: In intelligent manufacturing, robots are asked to dynamically adapt their behaviours without reducing productivity. Human teaching, where an operator physically interacts with the robot to demonstrate a new task, is a promising strategy to quickly and intuitively reconfigure the production line. However, physical guidance during task execution poses challenges in terms of both operator safety and system usability. In this paper, we solve this issue by designing a variable impedance control strategy that regulates the interaction with the environment and the physical demonstrations, explicitly preventing at the same time passivity violations. We derive constraints to limit not only the exchanged energy with the environment but also the exchanged power, resulting in smoother interactions. By monitoring the energy flow between the robot and the environment, we are able to distinguish between disturbances (to be rejected) and physical guidance (to be accomplished), enabling smooth and controlled transitions from teaching to execution and vice versa. The effectiveness of the proposed approach is validated in wiping tasks with a real robotic manipulator.
SaAT8 Special Session, Room T8 Add to My Program
Advancements in Modeling, Scheduling, and Control for Autonomous
Manufacturing I
Chair: Zhou, MengChu New Jersey Institute of Technology
Organizer: Kim, Hyun-Jung Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology
Organizer: Zhou, MengChu New Jersey Institute of Technology
10:00-10:15, Paper SaAT8.1 Add to My Program
Unlocking the Potential of Robot Manipulators: Seamless Integration Framework
Bueno Viso, Mikel Cranfield University
Bernardino, Irene Cranfield University
Asif, Seemal Cranfield University
Webb, Philip Cranfield University
Keywords: Intelligent and Flexible Manufacturing , Robust Manufacturing , Cyber-physical Production Systems and Industry 4.0
Abstract: This study introduces a groundbreaking framework designed to enhance the adaptability and efficiency of robot manipulators in manufacturing, leveraging ROS 2 and a modular middleware to transcend traditional robotic constraints. The framework's efficacy is exemplified through a pick-and-place task, serving not merely as a demonstration but as robust evidence of the framework's ability to enable complex object manipulation tasks far beyond repetitive activities. By integrating advanced perception capabilities with a YOLOv8-based object detection model and an OpenCV-based pose estimation module, the framework showcases a seamless interaction between sophisticated software tools and robotic hardware. This integration not only simplifies the incorporation of intelligent components into robotic systems but also significantly broadens their applicability and enhances efficiency across diverse tasks and applications. The use-case, therefore, stands as compelling evidence of the framework's potential to revolutionize industrial and collaborative robotics, providing a unified and adaptable platform for the development, testing, and deployment of robotic solutions in modern manufacturing settings. The research aims to simplify the integration of intelligent components into robotic systems, thereby extending their utility and efficiency across a broader range of tasks and applications, ultimately advancing the capabilities of industrial and collaborative robotics for modern manufacturing needs.
10:15-10:30, Paper SaAT8.2 Add to My Program
Solving an Integrated Order Batching, Picker Allocation and Batch Sequencing Problem Via Autoencoder-Embedded Iterated Local Search (I)
Lv, Xinsai Beijing University of Chemical Technology
Lin, Chengran Beijing University of Chemical Technology
Keywords: Planning, Scheduling and Coordination , Machine learning , Task Planning
Abstract: This work studies a warehouse scheduling problem including order batching, picker allocation and batch sequencing subproblems. To obtain its high-quality solutions in a short time, an Autoencoder-Embedded Iterated Local Search Algorithm (AEILS) is proposed. The main optimization algorithm is iterated local search. To reduce inefficient ``blind search" of AEILS, a long short-term memory network-embedded autoencoder model is proposed. The model captures the major features of solutions by using an improved one-hot encoding method. It compresses high-dimensional solutions into low-dimensional latent representations first, and then guides to generate promising offsprings in the resulting informative low-dimensional solution space. After that, some network-aided mutation operators are designed to improve the global search ability of AEILS. Simulations and comparisons with some competitive algorithms prove the efficiency and effectiveness of AEILS.
10:30-10:45, Paper SaAT8.3 Add to My Program
A Visual Object Detection and Counting System for Intelligent Casting Foundry Automation
Hsu, Yu-teng Feng Chia University
Chou, Che-Wei Feng Chia University
Keywords: Intelligent and Flexible Manufacturing , Computer Vision for Manufacturing , Factory Automation
Abstract: Visual recognition systems have been widely adopted in high-tech domains. For traditional manufacturing environments, particularly in the complex setting of foundries, deploying vision recognition systems remains highly challenging. The casting foundry environment is replete with disturbances such as debris and dust, limiting the performance of conventional object detection algorithms. The detected workpieces present challenges, including small components, object occlusions, and the difficulty of distinguishing similar objects. To address these challenges, we propose a visual object counting system that integrates object detection and tracking algorithm into manufacturing execution systems (MES). On the hardware, we design a real-time counting system tailored for foundry applications. On the software, we experimentally evaluate different visual recognition models to identify the most suitable one for the foundry scenario. This study effectively integrates the YOLO (You Only Look Once) visual object detection algorithm and Bytetrack for multi-object tracking with MES for casting foundry operations. Experimental results validate that our proposed real-time visual recognition counting system can indeed operate in foundry environments. However, there remains room for further optimization to enhance recognition accuracy.
10:45-11:00, Paper SaAT8.4 Add to My Program
Data-Mechanism-Driven Product Performance Optimization with Multiple Parameters under Uncertainties in Manufacturing Automation Systems (I)
Cui, Kaiyue Zhejiang University
Hong, Zhaoxi Zhejiang University
Song, Xiuju ZHEJIANG UNIVERSITY
Zhou, MengChu New Jersey Institute of Technology
Li, Zhiwu Xidian University
Feng, Yixiong Zhejiang University
Tan, Jianrong Zhejiang University
Keywords: Robust Manufacturing , AI-Based Methods , Human Factors and Human-in-the-Loop
Abstract: High-end equipment with robust and excellent performance is of great significance to manufacturing automation systems. Product parameters are the foundation of performance. Usually, there is a lack of clear physical models to reveal the relationship between parameters and performance. Simulation is an important way to understand the design results of product performance parameters. However, simulations are often particularly time and resource-consuming. To address these issues, this work proposes a data-mechanism-driven product performance optimization method, which introduces Taguchi' method, nonparametric correlation testing, and multiple attribute decision making (MADM), to efficiently obtain the optimal parameter scheme. A novel MADM method is designed, which is combined with the Multi-Objective Optimization on the basis of a Ratio Analysis plus the full MULTIplicative form (MULTIMOORA) and the Variable Neighborhood Search. It has been proven that it performs better than the MULTIMOORA based on the well-known Simulated Annealing and Tabu search. Finally, taking the cutting unit of EBZ200i as a case study, we have successfully obtained the optimal parameter scheme that comprehensively performs better in terms of wear performance, robustness, and environmental economic performance.

Smart and Sustainable Manufacturing I
Chair: Chang, Qing University of Virginia
Co-Chair: Frigerio, Nicla Politecnico Di Milano

10:00-10:15, Paper SaAT9.1 Add to My Program
A Systematic Literature Review on EV Battery Cell Stacking Process (I)
Bai, Sen Politecnico Di Milano
Frigerio, Nicla Politecnico Di Milano
Matta, Andrea Politecnico Di Milano
Keywords: Assembly , Intelligent and Flexible Manufacturing , Process Control
Abstract: Electric powertrain technologies are gaining widespread popularity globally during the transition to e-mobility. As a result, battery manufacturing technologies for electric vehicles (EVs) and fuel-efficient hybrid EVs are rapidly advancing, with a particular focus on the critical stacking process. The stacking process plays a key role, especially with the growing need of flexibility to accommodate new materials, sizes, and shapes in both conventional lithium-ion and solid-state batteries. Despite these developments, the current academic literature lacks a clear and systematic analysis of the stacking process. The proposed work aims to address this gap by discussing three main aspects: the stacking methods employed, enhancements made to the process, and advancements related to solid-state batteries. The discussion concludes with potential research directions based on the analysis outcomes.
10:15-10:30, Paper SaAT9.2 Add to My Program
Robot Learning from Demonstration Based on Human-In-The-Loop Reinforcement Learning (I)
Li, Chen University of Virginia
Yu, Tian University of Virginia
Chang, Qing University of Virginia
Keywords: Human Factors and Human-in-the-Loop , Motion and Path Planning , Reinforcement
Abstract: In the manufacturing industry, robots are typically pre-programmed to perform specific tasks. While this can be efficient and reliable for repetitive tasks, it limits the flexibility of the robots when task changes are necessary. This paper presents a new robot learning from demonstration method that combines kinematic task-space planning with human-in-the-loop hierarchical reinforcement learning. The approach allows a robot manipulator to efficiently learn new skills from demonstrations and intelligently combine primitive skills to adapt to new tasks in real-world manufacturing settings, thereby reducing the cost and effort required for robot re-programming in changing manufacturing environments.

Abstract: This abstract highlights ongoing efforts for bottleneck analysis in a Li-ion battery cell production system, which can lead to notable increases in system throughput. Such work provides a practical method for analysis and improvement of Li-ion battery cell production lines, along with other manufacturing systems.

Production and Changeover Control of Textile and PET Recycling (I)
El Achkar, Elias Politecnico Di Milano
Frigerio, Nicla Politecnico Di Milano
Keywords: Process Control , Optimization and Optimal Control , Discrete Event Dynamic Automation Systems
Abstract: This abstract focuses on PET recycling from plastic waste and textiles in the context of circular manufacturing systems. The problem of controlling the production of the recycling plant is investigated. We propose a model to control the production operative management assuming that two different quality feedstocks are available to be selected while requiring Quality-Based Changeovers (QBC) when the produced quality varies. The analysis of the response function is provided to understand the conditions for optimality and the areas where profit is maximized.

Early Design Phase: Solar HAPS UAV (I)
Bhattacharya, Anisha Rashtreeya Vidyalaya College of Engineering
C N, Lakshmi Manasa Rashtreeya Vidyalaya College of Engineering
Seetharamu, Sreevalli Rashtreeya Vidyalaya College of Engineering
Keywords: Product Design, Development and Prototyping , Simulation and Animation , Renewable Energy Sources
Abstract: High Altitude Pseudo Satellite (HAPS) Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) have been used and designed for various applications. They are inhibited by power restrictions which affect their performance. Recognizing the potential of solar energy at high altitudes, this study aims to conceptualize and design a solar-powered HAPS UAV for remote sensing and intelligence, surveillance and reconnaissance (ISR). The design was optimized for a final weight of 400.68 kilograms with a maximum span of 48.77 meters. Solar irradiation and power management system was modeled around the 30Â° latitude at the service ceiling of 20 kilometers.
10:15-10:30, Paper SaAT10.2 Add to My Program
Exploiting Interlaced Kalman Filter for Anomaly Detection (I)
Bonagura, Valeria Roma Tre
Chiara, Foglietta University of Roma Tre
Pascucci, Federica UniversitÃ  Roma Tre
Panzieri, Stefano UniversitÃ  Roma Tre
Keywords: Failure Detection and Recovery , Environment Monitoring and Management , Model Evolution (Systems and Software)
Abstract: This paper introduces a strategy for detecting integrity attacks in cyber-physical systems, like false data injection, in a distributed manner. The core of the proposed method lies in employing an Interlaced Kalman Filter. Each filter collects localized measurements related to the system's inputs and outputs, allowing for concurrent estimation of the overall system state. The exchange of state estimate and covariance matrices between neighboring filters enhances the precision of estimation. The algorithm has been enhanced to compensate for estimation uncertainty when subsystems cannot synchronize, with the aim of maximizing the consistency and content of the information.

Each filter incorporates a detection mechanism to identify measurement anomalies and prevent inaccurate estimations. Leveraging the central limit theorem, a batch analysis ensures higher estimation accuracy and consistency of the results.

Contributions of the paper include balancing computational burden and algorithmic complexity while addressing integrity attacks on sensor readings. The efficacy of the proposed algorithm is validated through a scenario involving nine water tanks grouped into four subsystems.

10:30-10:45, Paper SaAT10.3 Add to My Program
Polynomial Approximation of Regions of Attraction Via Occupation Measures: An Application to a Biological Autonomous System (I)
De Paola, Pierluigi Francesco National Research Council of Italy
Borri, Alessandro Italian National Research Council (IASI-CNR)
Paglialonga, Alessia Consiglio Nazionale Delle Ricerche (CNR)
Palumbo, Pasquale Consiglio Nazionale Delle Ricerche
Dabbene, Fabrizio CNR IEIIT
Keywords: Modelling, Simulation and Optimization in Healthcare , Optimization and Optimal Control
Abstract: In this work we analyze the problem of computing the regions of attraction of a well-acknowledged model in the framework of diabetes modeling and control, the model by Topp et al. Despite the importance of this pioneering model in the literature of mathematical models of diabetes progression, to the best of our knowledge a clear representation of the regions of attraction of specific target sets under suitable conditions appears to be lacking. We address this problem by means of a method employing moment-sum-of-squares (moment-SOS)hierarchy that we exploit to assess the validity of a general computation of the regions of attraction performed through a Monte Carlo simulation. Addressing the problem of the knowledge of certain region of attraction, this work paves the way to future research aimed at exploiting a polynomial version of diabetes progression models to leverage optimal control problem design via occupation measures and moment-SOS hierarchy.

Security and Localization of Cyber Attacks in Finite State Machines (I)
Bushra, Bushra Politecnico Di Bari
De Santis, Elena University of L' Aquila
Pola, Giordano University of L'Aquila
Keywords: Discrete Event Dynamic Automation Systems
Abstract: The inspiration for this work is the rising possibility of cyber attacks, making security a critical problem in many applications. This work addresses two key problems related to the security of a Finite State Machine (FSM): attack detection and localization. A composition of nominal plant and the attacker FSM is developed to analyze different security aspects, under actuator attacks, and necessary and sufficient conditions are developed for attack detection. In some cases, the intruder can make replacements in the sensor or actuator channel. From the security perspective, it is important to identify the attacked channel. The term localization is used, to detect the attacked channel, and necessary and sufficient conditions are provided that ensure localization
10:45-11:00, Paper SaAT10.5 Add to My Program
Integrating Occupancy Grid with Semantic Road Information for Autonomous Navigation in Urban Scenarios: A Benchmark Study (I)
Felicioni, Simone University of Perugia - Department of Engineering
Burani, Elena UniversitÃ  Di Perugia
Leomanni, Mirko University of Perugia
Fravolini, Mario Luca University of Perugia
Valigi, Paolo Universita' Di Perugia
Costante, Gabriele University of Perugia
Keywords: Autonomous Vehicle Navigation , Intelligent Transportation Systems , Deep Learning in Robotics and Automation
Abstract: In the last decades, autonomous vehicles (AVs) have attracted the interest of industries and researchers to develop and improve the performance of advanced driver assistance systems (ADAS). To this aim, many works focus on extracting semantic information in urban scenarios to increase the autonomy of the vehicles toward safe and more efficient self-driving navigation. Following this research direction, classical grid representations of the world can be extended to semantic occupancy grids, that include richer information by assigning semantic labels to the grid cells. However, the literature lacks a comparison between existing approaches and a study on how semantic mapping may affect the autonomous navigation performance. In our investigation, we consider four state-of-the-art methods and compare the computation times along with the navigation performance, by highlighting the pros and cons of each strategy.
10:45-11:00, Paper SaAT10.6 Add to My Program
Chattering-Free Sliding Mode Control for Position and Attitude Tracking of a Quadrotor with a Cable-Suspended Load (I)
Gomiero, Sara Free University of Bolzano-Bozen
von Ellenrieder, Karl Florida Atlantic University
Keywords: Autonomous Vehicle Navigation , Robust/Adaptive Control , Motion Control
Abstract: There are diverse applications in industry, agriculture and logistics which can benefit from the use of quadrotor Uncrewed Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) with cable-suspended payloads. Their control is a challenging topic, given the nonlinear and underactuated dynamics of the UAV and the oscillations of the cargo. In this work, we propose a chattering-free sliding mode controller (SMC) for position and attitude tracking of a quadrotor with a cable-suspended payload. Firstly, the model of the UAV and the load is derived via Lagrangian approach in matrix form. Then, the system is divided into two subsystems and four sliding mode controllers are designed. The chattering effect is eliminated via approximation of the signum function with a saturation function. Moreover, our approach permits computation of the sliding surface coefficients using a simple linearization of the dynamic model and Hurwitz analysis. The stability of the closed-loop controller is proven via Lyapunov theory and its effectiveness is validated through simulations. The proposed SMC allows to track the desired references when a quadrotor of 1.1 kg performs non-aggressive maneuvers, transporting a payload of 0.2 kg with a cable of 1 m. In this scenario, our approach ensures that the oscillations of the load are always smaller than 4.6 degrees.
SaAT11 Special Session, Room T11 Add to My Program
Digital Twin in Smart Construction I
Chair: Zhao, Zhiheng The Hong Kong Polytechnic University
Co-Chair: Xu, Gangyan The Hong Kong Polytechnic University
Organizer: Zhao, Zhiheng The Hong Kong Polytechnic University
Organizer: Xu, Gangyan The Hong Kong Polytechnic University

Organizer: Pan, Wei The University of Hong Kong

Organizer: Chen, Qiqi The Hong Kong Polytechnic University
Organizer: Li, Ming The Hong Kong Polytechnic University
Organizer: Huang, George Q. The University of Hong Kong
10:00-10:15, Paper SaAT11.1 Add to My Program
Digital Twin-Driven Automatic Response Analysis for Demolition Safety (I)
Zhu, Zhengxu The University of Hong Kong
Zhao, Shuxuan The University of Hongkong
Guo, Xinyue The University of Hong Kong
Zhong, Ray Y. The University of Hong Kong
Keywords: Automation in Construction
Abstract: Abstractâ€”As one of the most dangerous construction projects, demolition brings many potential risks. Mechanical response analysis can evaluate the stress on complex structures, thereby improving construction safety. To conduct real-time analysis of demolition sites where building structures change at any time, this study proposed an automatic response analysis process based on digital twins. A case study based on this process has been implemented for Tenement building in Hong Kong. Systematic modeling techniques were used to evaluate the damage to the tense building during the demolition process. At the same time, the analysis also considered pre-existing cracks that commonly existed in old buildings. The predicted response indicates that cracks amplify vibration inputs and increase structural instability. This provides a new reference for developing flexible and safe construction plans.
10:15-10:30, Paper SaAT11.2 Add to My Program
DT-PoseFormer: A Digital Twin-Enabled Transformer Network for Precise Pose Estimation of MiC Modules (I)
Han, Yujie The Hong Kong Polytechnic University
Xie, Jingda Nanjing University of Posts and Telecomunications, the Hong Kong
Ding, Jiyuchen Nanjing University of Posts and Telecommunications, the Hong Kong
Zhao, Zhiheng The Hong Kong Polytechnic University
Huang, George Q. The University of Hong Kong
Keywords: Collision Avoidance , Sensor Fusion , Compliant Assembly
Abstract: High installation accuracy of Modular Integrated Construction (MiC) is crucial to prevent structural damage, minimize safety incidents and enhance the efficiency. However, due to the complex dynamic construction environment and the uncertain installation process, few studies have been conducted on the pose and trajectory tracking of the module. The installation process of the modules lacks a reliable guidance system and relies almost entirely on the visual inspection and installation experience of the construction workers. Analyzing the hidden interactions and trajectories utilizing real-time spatio-temporal information of MiC assets has the potential to address the challenges of inaccurate module stacking. Therefore, in this paper, a Digital Twin (DT)-based pose estimation system with Transformer Network is proposed. Firstly, the information of workers, cranes, and 6-dimensional MiC module information is collected and updated by Ultra-Wide Band (UWB) and Inertial Measurement Unit (IMU) sensors for building DT virtual assets. Secondly, a DT framework incorporating the complex on-site environment is proposed to visualize the stacking process so as to guide the crane driver. Thirdly, a novel PoseFormer network is proposed as the backend of the DT framework to perform real-time pose estimation for the modules. Finally, the PoseFormer is compared with the current state-of-the-art deep learning model. The performance of our model is much better than the other models, which proves the high superiority of PoseFormer.
10:30-10:45, Paper SaAT11.3 Add to My Program
Design and Development of a Shape Measurement System for 3D Construction Printing with a Manipulator
Nakanishi, Reina Shimizu Corporation
Ogura, Hiroki Shimizu Corporation
Yamamoto, Shinya Shimizu Corporation
Abe, Hiroyuki Shimizu Corporation
Kikuchi, Ryu Shimizu Corporation
Keywords: Automation in Construction , Sustainable Production and Service Automation , Factory Automation
Abstract: We describe a 3D construction printing system comprising an industrial robot with a six-degrees-of-freedom manipulator and a pump that supplies mortar. Printing is realized by linking the manipulator to the pump. To measure and evaluate printed object shapes, we attached a time-of-flight camera with +- 2 mm measurement accuracy to an end effector mounted on the manipulator, thereby acquiring point-cloud data for printed objects. Using software developed to control the manipulator, and an open-source robotics middleware suite as the robot operating system, we merge the obtained point clouds. After printing mortar objects, we use the developed system to measure their shapes. Experimental results show that point clouds for printed objects have errors of 0 to 10 mm, while data from a conventional stationary 3D laser scanner has measurement accuracy of +- 1 mm. Although merged point clouds show increased errors, measurement times decreased to approximately one-sixth those of conventional scanners. The increased error is likely due to factors such as the manipulator's weight and its installation at the end effector and the sensor. We use a total station to measure deflections to confirm the manipulator's positioning accuracy.
10:45-11:00, Paper SaAT11.4 Add to My Program
Real-Time Locating System-Enabled Digital Twin for Crane Operation Safety Monitoring on Construction Sites (I)
Li, Peisen The Hong Kong Polytechnic University
Xie, Jingda Nanjing University of Posts and Telecomunications, the Hong Kong
Ding, Jiyuchen Nanjing University of Posts and Telecommunications, the Hong Kong
Zhao, Zhiheng The Hong Kong Polytechnic University
Wu, Wei Chongqing Univeristy
Huang, George Q. The University of Hong Kong
Keywords: Collision Avoidance , Sensor Fusion , Automation in Construction
Abstract: Crane loads present a significant safety concern on construction sites. Numerous studies have employed the real-time locating system (RTLS) to identify crane load fall zones where crane loads may fall in the event of an accident. However, previous studies often assumed that the fall zone directly beneath the load was static and of a fixed size. In fact, the crane load fall zone is dynamic, varying with the movement of the crane jib and the geometric attribute of different crane loads. The dynamic identification of load fall zones to mitigate corresponding safety risks for on-site workers presents a complex challenge. In this paper, we design the RTLS-enabled digital twin for crane operation safety monitoring on construction sites for modular integrated construction (MiC). First, the improved algorithm is designed to dynamically identify the load fall zone associated with different prefabs. Second, we utilize an ultra-wideband (UWB) technology and time difference of arrival (TDoA) algorithm to pinpoint on-site workers in potential danger. Finally, safety warnings are provided to crane operators and on-site workers in potential danger zones to mitigate safety risks. Tests were conducted in a controlled laboratory environment to validate the proposed methodology. The results indicate that the system is effective in identifying dangerous zones, detecting worker proximity, and generating timely safety warnings, which can effectively mitigate safety risks on construction sites.
SaAT12 Regular Session, Room T12 Add to My Program
Human Gait Reconstruction
Chair: Guarino Lo Bianco, Corrado University of Parma
Co-Chair: Wei, Dunwen University of Electronic Science and Technology of China
10:00-10:15, Paper SaAT12.1 Add to My Program
Knee Exoskeleton-Enabled Balance Control of Human Walking Gait with Unexpected Foot Slip
Zhu, Chunchu Rutgers University
Yi, Jingang Rutgers University
Keywords: Physical Human-Robot Interaction , Prosthetics and Exoskeletons , Human Performance Augmentation
Abstract: Foot slip is one of the leading causes of fall-related injuries during human walking. The underlying slip dynamics help understand bipedal recoverability under gait perturbation and therefore provide a tool to design proactive slip-induced fall prevention strategies. We present a new integrated wearable sensing and exoskeleton-enabled fall prevention under unexpected foot slip. The real-time slip detection is realized with a set of small, wearable inertial measurements units on both legs. We use the balance recoverability and inter-limb coordination analyses to design the balance recovery strategies. The bilateral knee exoskeleton provides assistive torque control and helps walker to follow the designed gait recovery strategies. Multiple subject experiments are presented to demonstrate the exoskeleton-enabled recovery under foot slip. Various critical metrics, including slip distance, velocity, swing leg touch-down time, etc., are systematically compared to assess the efficacy of both the exoskeleton and the controller. The results confirm that incorporating knee exoskeletons as a balance recovery method for human walking is a reliable and robust approach to mitigate or prevent slip-induced falls.
10:15-10:30, Paper SaAT12.2 Add to My Program
Multi-Sensor and Deep Learning Based Ankle Joint Motion Intention Prediction under Diverse Gait Speed Conditions
Gong, Jumin University of Electronic Science and Technology of China
Wei, Dunwen University of Electronic Science and Technology of China
Gao, Tao University of Electronic Science and Technology of China
Liu, Zekun University of Electronic Science and Technology of China
Keywords: Deep Learning in Robotics and Automation , Sensor Fusion , AI and Machine Learning in Healthcare
Abstract: Motion intention prediction is an essential challenge in improving the efficacy of exoskeleton human-machine interactions. Traditional gait phase detection and motion pattern recognition methods can only identify the current gait state, lacking the ability to adjust motion parameters based on step speed dynamically, and real-time performance is difficult to guarantee. In this paper, we proposed a deep learning model TCN-LSTM, which integrated Time Convolutional Network (TCN) and Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM), to predict human ankle joint angles under different walking speeds based on data from Inertial Measurement Unit (IMU) and Goniometer (GON). We selected 5 subjects in a public dataset for experimental validation. Experimental results demonstrated that the proposed model could accurately and rapidly predict ankle joint angles. The MAE of the individualspecific model was 1.191Â°, outperforming the 3 baseline models: LSTM (1.750Â°), Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU) (1.653Â°), and TCN (1.340Â°). The Mean Absolute Error (MAE) of the general model is reduced by 14.3% compared to the 3 baseline models. The prediction error of TCN-LSTM with GON is reduced by 13.69%. Furthermore, the average prediction time of our model is only 3.7ms. Therefore, the accuracy and real-time performance of the model can meet the continuous prediction of human ankle joint angle.
10:30-10:45, Paper SaAT12.3 Add to My Program
Standing to Sitting Assistance - Control Strategy for an Assistive Robotic Chair Based on Human Motion Prediction
Basei, Elena University of Trento
Furukawa, Jun-ichiro Guardian Robot Project, RIKEN
Ito, Takahide Guardian Robot Project, RIKEN
An, Qi The University of Tokyo
Morimoto, Jun Kyoto University
Keywords: Physically Assistive Devices
Abstract: In the last decade, there has been a significant rise in the number of older adults requiring physical assistance. The current medical staff cannot guarantee assistance to all those in need. Therefore, it is essential to find alternative solutions to support people with limited mobility. This study focuses on the Standing-to-Sitting (STS) motion, a simple but challenging motion for older and impaired individuals. We propose a control strategy for a robotic chair based on predicting sitting intention with an RGB camera. Our approach involves deep neural networks (DNNs) to predict human motion and detect sitting intention. To validate our approach, we compared its performance with two baseline methods. Results show that our approach predicts sitting intention with higher accuracy a few seconds earlier than baseline methods. In real-time tests, our approach reduces the impact force during sitting and achieves a smooth transition from standing to sitting.
10:45-11:00, Paper SaAT12.4 Add to My Program
An Adaptive Gait Planner for a Lower-Limb Exoskeleton Ascending Staircases of Unknown Geometry
Raineri, Marina University of Parma
Guarino Lo Bianco, Corrado University of Parma
Keywords: Prosthetics and Exoskeletons , Physically Assistive Devices , Rehabilitation
Abstract: The staircase ascent motion is a physical activity which is very common in everyday life, but it is very challenging for people who suffer for Spinal Cord Injury (SCI). Active exoskeletons can help patients to regain a certain degree of mobility, but their design require facing some difficult problems: smart exoskeletons need to perceive the environment and, in turn, adapt the gait, so as to guarantee a smooth and safe motion. In such a context, this work proposes a solution for a staircase ascending problem. It exploits low cost ranging sensors for the environment reconstruction and a real-time trajectory planner for the generation of an adaptive gait which accounts for the steps geometry. The strength of the proposed technique is represented by the continuous update method -- adopted for both the environment reconstruction and the path planning -- which allows for a safe ascent. The proposed method was tested through simulations and real experiments.
SaBT1 Special Session, Room T1 Add to My Program
Energy Communities: Optimization and Control for Sustainability
Organizer: Parodi, Luca University of Genoa
Organizer: Casella, Virginia University of Genoa
Organizer: Robba, Michela University of Genoa
Organizer: Ferro, Giulio University of Genoa
Organizer: Carli, Raffaele Politecnico Di Bari
