11:30-11:45, Paper SaBT8.1 Add to My Program
A Q-Learning-Based Meta-Heuristic Algorithm for Open Shop Scheduling Considering Group and Transportation Activities (I)
Wang, Yifeng Qingdao University
Ji, Mengyao Qingdao University
Fu, Yaping Qingdao University
Wang, Hongfeng Northeastern University
Gao, Kaizhou NTU
Keywords: Intelligent and Flexible Manufacturing , Manufacturing, Maintenance and Supply Chains , Logistics
Abstract: Open shop scheduling problems have received considerable attention in recent years, and they are extensively implemented in manufacturing and service systems. Group and transportation activities play pivotal roles in reality, but they attract less concern. This article studies an open shop scheduling problem considering group and transportation operations via addressing group allocation of jobs, job sequence in groups and group processing route on machines. Firstly, a mixed integer programming model is developed to define the problem for minimizing makespan. Secondly, a Q-learning-based meta-heuristic algorithm is devised by integrating a Q-learning method and three meta-heuristic methods, i.e., genetic algorithm, variable neighborhood search approach and Jaya algorithm. The Q-learning method is employed to choose an appropriate meta-heuristic as the search method during iterations. Finally, through comparison experiments with two state-of-the-art meta-heuristics, the competitiveness of the proposed model and method is identified in solving the concerned problems.
11:45-12:00, Paper SaBT8.2 Add to My Program
Multi-Agent Scheduler for the Continuous Dynamic Flexible Job Shop Scheduling Problem (I)
Johnson, Dazzle Department of Mechanical and Mechatronics Engineering, the Unive
Chen, Gang Victoria University of Wellington
Lu, Yuqian The University of Auckland
Keywords: Planning, Scheduling and Coordination , Foundations of Automation , Reinforcement
Abstract: This work addresses the unique production challenges in dynamic smart manufacturing environments caused by the shift towards mass personalisation. Traditional scheduling methods do not perform reliably in a continuously operating environment with unpredictable job order arrivals, a variety of products and urgent orders, leading to increased tardiness and inefficiencies. To reflect the challenges dynamic manufacturing environments face, we introduce a new problem â€“ the Continuous Dynamic Flexible Job Shop Scheduling Problem (C-DFJSP). In response, we propose MAC-Sched â€“ a Multi-Agent Continuous Scheduler. MAC-Sched is a Graph-Based Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning model that takes a graph representation of the manufacturing environment as input, thus enabling the continuous and reliable production of personalised products. Demonstrating its reliability in multiple unseen continuous operating environments, MAC-Sched outperforms popular heuristic rules, effectively minimising the average tardiness over time amid evolving factory dynamics.
12:00-12:15, Paper SaBT8.3 Add to My Program
Block Relocation Problem with Deep Reinforcement Learning (I)
Jung, Ji-Kwang Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology
Cho, Sang-Hyun Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology
Shin, Woo-Jin Korea Advanced Institute of Science & Technology
Kim, Hyun-Jung Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology
Keywords: Reinforcement , Planning, Scheduling and Coordination , Deep Learning in Robotics and Automation
Abstract: The block relocation problem (BRP), also recognized as the container relocation problem, stands as one of the extensively investigated combinatorial optimization problems within container terminals. In container terminals, stacks of containers often make it hard to access specific ones. When a certain container is buried under others, the containers above the target container have to be moved to another stack, a process called "relocation." The primary objective of BRP is to minimize the number of block relocations while retrieving all items based on their priorities. We propose a novel deep reinforcement learning-based approach to solve BRP. With techniques, such as long short-term memory networks and multi-head attention layers, our model aims to provide a solution across a wide range of scenarios. The experimental results indicate that our model outperforms other prior works, including heuristics and meta-heuristics within a feasible time.
12:15-12:30, Paper SaBT8.4 Add to My Program
Analysis and Control of Time Delays in a Cluster Tool for a Cyclic Schedule (I)
Kim, Min-Chan Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology
Kim, Hyun-Jung Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology
Keywords: Planning, Scheduling and Coordination , Semiconductor Manufacturing , Optimization and Optimal Control
Abstract: We analyze the impact of time delays on cluster tool scheduling. Recent advancements in wafer fabs have highlighted the detrimental effects of time delays, specifically the redundant sojourn time of wafers within cluster tools, on the quality of the end-product. Consequently, there is a growing need to minimize these delays to uphold stringent quality control standards. However, due to resource synchronization challenges, quantifying time delays in a general mathematical equation has proven difficult. As a result, analysis of this issue has mostly been fragmented, focusing on specific scenarios. In this paper, we lay the groundwork for analyzing time delays by establishing a theoretical framework. We show that these delays can indeed be expressed in closed-form formulas. Additionally, by examining time delays under conventional robot sequences, we offer insights into both productivity and quality perspectives.
12:30-12:45, Paper SaBT8.5 Add to My Program
Noncyclic Scheduling of Single-Armed Cluster Tools with Multiple Wafer Types and Wafer Residency Time Constraints Using Deep Reinforcement Learning (I)
Kim, Duyeon Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology
Kim, Min-Chan Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology
Kim, Hyun-Jung Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology
Keywords: Deep Learning in Robotics and Automation , Reinforcement , Planning, Scheduling and Coordination
Abstract: Due to the recent increase in semiconductor demand, the efficient concurrent processing of small lots in a cluster tool has become a major concern in both industry and academia. In this study, we propose a reinforcement learning framework for cluster tool scheduling, effectively learning a robot move policy while satisfying the wafer residency constraints during concurrent processing. Our graph attention network-based model determines the robot move sequence, and robot move timing is determined using a robot move graph and a Bellman-Ford algorithm. We experimentally verified that our framework can generate efficient schedules without violating residency constraints in the single-armed cluster tool problem environment.
12:45-13:00, Paper SaBT8.6 Add to My Program
Analysis of Backward Sequence in Lot Switching Periods for Single-Armed Cluster Tools (I)
Ahn, Jeongsun KAIST
Kim, Hyun-Jung Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology
Keywords: Planning, Scheduling and Coordination , Semiconductor Manufacturing , Factory Automation
Abstract: Due to the increasing diameter of wafers and diverse customer demands, cluster tools frequently encounter lot switching periods, where wafer lots with different recipes are processed consecutively. Many previous studies have often used the backward sequence, which is considered optimal for cyclic robot operations with identical lots. This practice persists even when addressing lot switching period scheduling. Nevertheless, it remains uncertain whether the backward sequence is the optimal choice or can guarantee a specific level of performance during the transient periods. Therefore, we analyze the performance of the backward sequence in lot switching periods of single-armed cluster tools, both theoretically and experimentally for the first time. We first conduct an analysis of the dominance relations among backward operations, then propose a workload concept for the lot switching period and establish the conditions under which the backward sequence provides an optimal schedule. We finally empirically verify the effectiveness and performance of the backward sequence.
SaBT9 Special Session, Room T9 Add to My Program
Smart and Sustainable Manufacturing II
Chair: Frigerio, Nicla Politecnico Di Milano
Organizer: Chang, Qing University of Virginia
Organizer: Li, Congbo Chongqing University
Organizer: Wu, Wei Chongqing Univeristy
Organizer: Ju, Feng Arizona State University
Organizer: Frigerio, Nicla Politecnico Di Milano
11:30-11:45, Paper SaBT9.1 Add to My Program
Production Planning and Allocation of Re-Entrance Flows with Stochastic Quality (I)
Shen, Xiaoxiao Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Politecnico Di Milano
Frigerio, Nicla Politecnico Di Milano
Du, Shichang Shanghai JiaoTong University
Matta, Andrea Politecnico Di Milano
Keywords: Sustainability and Green Automation , Remanufacturing , Intelligent and Flexible Manufacturing
Abstract: Circular production promotes economic growth while conserving resources and energy. In this study, one aspect of production systems, the repair loop of returned products, is considered. The production system is composed of multiple flexible workstations that can process returns with different quality levels. This system aims to complete order production and deliver it on time by optimizing the use of the given resource levels. A sequential decision-making approach is employed to obtain rolling production decisions over a finite planning horizon. At each decision period, the manufacturer needs to simultaneously determine the optimal repair allocation plans for first returns and their potential second returns that will be back after certain periods. For traceability and quality reasons, a product at each return is required to be repaired on the same workstation; otherwise, a penalty cost is imposed. A stochastic mixed-integer programming model is developed based on sample average approximation (SAA) method, where the quality level of the second return is stochastic. Numerical results demonstrate that the value of the stochastic solution is significant compared with the average performance of solutions obtained by the existing deterministic model. Useful guidelines related to stochastic solutions and optimal capacity allocation patterns are also provided for production practices.
11:45-12:00, Paper SaBT9.2 Add to My Program
Efficient Job Shop Scheduling Via Graph Based Deep Reinforcement Learning with Adaptive Multi-Action Selection (I)
Park, Jeongwon Arizona State University
Su, Yutong Arizona State University
Ju, Feng Arizona State University
Keywords: Optimization and Optimal Control , Planning, Scheduling and Coordination , Machine learning
Abstract: The Job Shop Scheduling Problem (JSSP) is a widely studied combinatorial optimization challenge with significant real-world applications, characterized by its NP-hard complexity. Priority dispatching rule (PDR) is a widely used heuristic to solve JSSP. Unfortunately, designing an appropriate PDR is time-consuming. In this paper, we present an efficient solution to the JSSP by introducing a novel framework based on a weighted Graph Isomorphic Network and deep reinforcement learning. Our approach involves representing JSSP through a disjunctive graph, reformulating it as a Markov decision process. A weighted Graph Isomorphic Network is generated to learn the representation of the disjunctive graph of JSSP during solving, with weights given by the relationship between a pair of nodes. The Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) is used to train the policy network to get high-quality PDRs. To enhance computational efficiency, we introduce an adaptive multi-action selection strategy. We evaluate the performance of the proposed method on public JSSP benchmark instances and compare it with other well-known dispatching rules. The experiment results show that our proposed method achieves the shortest makespan. The incorporation of the adaptive multi-action selection strategy further enhances the efficiency of our approach without significant degradation in scheduling performance.
12:00-12:15, Paper SaBT9.3 Add to My Program
Mechanical Design Parameter Optimization through Graph-Based Bayesian Optimization and Pseudo Labeling (I)
Li, Guoyan Northeastern University
Jin, Xiaoning Northeastern University
Keywords: AI-Based Methods , Optimization and Optimal Control , Additive Manufacturing
Abstract: This paper introduces a new methodology aimed at expediting the determination of optimal design parameters. Due to the substantial expenses associated with the manual annotation process, Bayesian Optimization (BayesOpt) is extensively employed within engineering optimization to substantially reduce the need for labor-intensive manual labeling through experimentation. BayesOpt involves a closed-loop where a probabilistic surrogate model is trained iteratively to guide sequential experimental design. Traditional BayesOpt methods that leverage a small labeled dataset to quantify the unlabeled information usually start a pure exploration of the whole design space in the initial optimization phase, which causes an over-exploration problem. In this work, we aim to improve the efficiency of exploring the entire design space by implementing a graph-based Gaussian Process as a surrogate model, which integrates geometric information within the design space. In addition, we designed a pseudo-label generator, which estimates the labels of informative, yet unlabeled data, thereby expanding the training dataset. This new framework enhances the learning efficiency of the surrogate model, enabling more precise and faster design space exploration for optimal design. We validated the effectiveness of our proposed approach through simulation data and applied this method to optimize mechanical structures in the additive manufacturing process.
12:15-12:30, Paper SaBT9.4 Add to My Program
Modeling and Analysis for Inherent Energy Efficiency of Two-Machine Bernoulli Serial Lines (I)
Longyao, Xu Chongqing University
Liu, Peiji Chongqing University
Wang, Xu Chongqing University
Yu, Fangyuan Chongqing University
Liu, Chao Aston University
Keywords: Sustainable Production and Service Automation , Sustainability and Green Automation
Abstract: In recent years, the topic of balancing the energy efficiency of production systems with production performance parameters such as productivity and buffer capacity has received increasing attention. However, the existing research generally focuses on the operational energy efficiency of the production systemï¼Œwhich may changes with various workpieces and make it difficult to support the formation and optimization of high-efficiency production lines. For this reason, we firstly propose the inherent energy efficiency of production systems to describe the common characteristics of the operational energy efficiency that do not vary with workpiece changes when production systems machining various possible future workpieces. Secondly, the specific inherent energy efficiency model which based on the unreliability of the production unit and the limited capacity of the product buffer of the Bernoulli two-machine serial production system has been established. Then a mathematical analysis method oriented to the optimal solution for the production line buffer capacity and the inherent energy efficiency has been proposed. Finally, numerical analysis is used to verify that the models and methods proposed in this paper are instructive for energy-efficient design and upgrading of production systems.
12:30-12:45, Paper SaBT9.5 Add to My Program
Data-Driven Ergonomic Risk Assessment of Complex Hand-Intensive Manufacturing Processes (I)
Krishnan, Anand University of Washington
Yang, Xingjian University of Washington
Seth, Utsav Duke University
M. Jeyachandran, Jonathan The Boeing Company
Y. Ahn, Jonathan The Boeing Company
J. Gardner, Richard The Boeing Company
Pedigo, Samuel The Boeing Company
Blom-Schieber, Agnes The Boeing Company
Banerjee, Ashis University of Washington
Manohar, Krithika University of Washington
Keywords: Human Factors and Human-in-the-Loop , Sensor Fusion , Machine learning
Abstract: Hand-intensive manufacturing processes, such as composite layup and textile draping, require significant human dexterity to accommodate task complexity. These strenuous hand motions often lead to musculoskeletal disorders and rehabilitation surgeries. We develop a data-driven ergonomic risk assessment system with a special focus on hand and finger activity to better identify and address ergonomic issues related to hand-intensive manufacturing processes. The system comprises a multi-modal sensor testbed to collect and synchronize operator upper body pose, hand pose, and applied forces; a Biometric Assessment of Complete Hand (BACH) formulation to measure high-fidelity hand and finger risks; and industry-standard risk scores associated with upper body posture, RULA, and hand activity, HAL. Our findings demonstrate that BACH captures injurious activity with a higher granularity in comparison to the existing metrics. Machine learning models are also used to automate RULA and HAL scoring, and generalize well to unseen participants. Our assessment system, therefore, provides ergonomic interpretability of the manufacturing processes studied and could be used to mitigate risks through minor workplace optimization and posture corrections.
12:45-13:00, Paper SaBT9.6 Add to My Program
A Sample Path-Based Method for the Digital Twin Prediction Update Synchronization Problem of Unreliable Production Lines (I)
Gou, Yi-Xing Northwestern Polytechnical University
Matta, Andrea Politecnico Di Milano
Tan, BarÄ±ÅŸ Ozyegin University
Keywords: Cyber-physical Production Systems and Industry 4.0 , Discrete Event Dynamic Automation Systems , Manufacturing, Maintenance and Supply Chains
Abstract: The adoption of IoT technologies enables easy and cheap data collection and more efficient digital twin operations. The available data are used to align the digital twin with its physical system. However, too frequent information exchange between physical and digital systems leads to high latency and costs and affects production decisions. The digital twin synchronization problem determines whether or not to synchronize the digital twin at each observation period depending on the observed state of the physical system. Existing approaches provide solutions for the prediction update synchronization problem, but they can be applied only to simple systems. In this study, we propose a sample path-based method to solve the prediction update synchronization problem for unreliable production lines composed of multiple machines and finite buffers. The method requires estimating the performance measure for each synchronization decision by partially observing the state of the system. An optimal state-dependent synchronization policy is determined based on the observed state to balance the prediction bias and the synchronization cost. The results show that observing the state of the most crucial machine in the production line, i.e., the bottleneck machine, rather than fully observing the state of the system, is efficient for solving the problem without requiring a very long sample path.

Decision and Control Techniques for Autonomous Systems II
Chair: GiarrÃ¨, Laura UniversitÃ  Di Modena E Reggio Emilia
Co-Chair: Pascucci, Federica UniversitÃ  Roma Tre
Organizer: GiarrÃ¨, Laura UniversitÃ  Di Modena E Reggio Emilia
Organizer: Cavallo, Alberto Seconda UniversitÃ  Degli Studi Di Napoli
Organizer: Pascucci, Federica UniversitÃ  Roma Tre
Organizer: Carli, Raffaele Politecnico Di Bari
11:30-11:45, Paper SaBT10.1 Add to My Program
Resilient Networks for Multi-Agent Systems Based on Graph Self-Organization into Random Approximate Regular Graphs (I)
Zhao, Wenjie Xidian University, University of Cagliari
Deplano, Diego University of Cagliari
Li, Zhiwu Xidian Univeristy
Giua, Alessandro University of Cagliari, Italy
Franceschelli, Mauro University of Cagliari, Italy
Keywords: Agent-Based Systems , Autonomous Agents , Robot Networks
Abstract: This paper proposes a distributed protocol that can self-organize a connected graph representing a network into a random approximate regular graph with an arbitrary degree, which is known to possess robustness properties against link and node failures, including also DoS network attacks. The scenario under consideration is that of an unstructured peer-to-peer network, where the agents and are allowed to close communications with their neighbors and establish new communications with two-hop neighbor, while the time-varying graph topology remains unknown. To validate the efficacy of the proposed protocol, we examine the spectral properties of the self-organizing graph, and we numerically show that they approach those of random regular graphs, particularly for large networks. We also compare the performance of the proposed protocol with the state-of-the-art, showing improvements in convergence speed and scalability, despite the absence of synchronous multi-node coordination of previous approaches in the literature.
11:45-12:00, Paper SaBT10.2 Add to My Program
Sensor Fusion-Based Autonomous Flight Method for Drone Inspection of Power Facilities (I)
Jeon, Munsu Hanyang University
Moon, Joonhyeok Hanyang University
Siheon, Jeong Hanyang University
Oh, Ki-Yong Hanyang University
Keywords: Sensor-based Control , AI-Based Methods , Data fusion
Abstract: This study proposes a sensor fusion-based autonomous flight method for drone inspection of power facilities. The proposed method utilizes the novel deep neural network alongside various unsupervised learning approaches to enhance the effectiveness of autonomous drone flights for power facility inspection. Our approach is divided into two distinct stages. In the initial stage, when the drone begins autonomous flight mission, it employs a sophisticated deep neural network known as the RoMP Transformer to identify nearby power transmission towers using optical imagery. Based on the images captured by the RoMP Transformer, the drone plots a navigational course towards the desired power transmission tower and proceeds along this route. The second stage is triggered when the drone comes within safety distance of the power transmission tower. At this close range, it integrates data from both an optical camera and a 3D LiDAR sensor to further refine its path. This stage features the application of several unsupervised learning techniques that process the LiDAR-generated point cloud data of the power transmission lines. This analysis helps in real-time creation and following of a trajectory that traces the power transmission lines precisely. This innovative methodology not only improves the autonomy of drone inspections but also enhances their safety and efficiency by adapting in real-time to the environment.
12:00-12:15, Paper SaBT10.3 Add to My Program
Embodied Runtime Monitoring of Learning-Enabled Robot Perception Components (I)
Nair, Deebul Sivarajan Hochschule Bonn-Rhein-Sieg
Panchangam, Sathwik Hochschule Bonn Rhein Sieg University of Applied Sciences
Olivares-Mendez, Miguel A. Interdisciplinary Centre for Security, Reliability and Trust - U
Hochgeschwender, Nico University of Bremen
Keywords: Failure Detection and Recovery , Control Architectures and Programming , Deep Learning in Robotics and Automation
Abstract: Monitoring during runtime, the estimated uncertainty from learning-enabled robot perception components, is a vital tool for assuring and evaluating model correctness. By utilizing different uncertainty estimation methods, monitors exploit the perceived sensor data and predictions generated by the perception model to make informed decisions, such as in safety-critical situations. In robotics, informed decisions should be aligned with embodied information regarding space and time. We argue and show that runtime monitors of learning-enabled components can be made more robust by including the embodiment information of the robot. However, it remains challenging to build uncertainty-based runtime monitors with embodiment information using only real-world datasets, which are tedious to collect. To this end, we propose a solution that leverages simulation-based datasets to characterize expected uncertainty estimates with robot embodiment. By constructing a nominal runtime monitor model based on simulated datasets, we establish a reference for the expected uncertainty along with the embodiment information that can be subsequently used to monitor real-world deployed perception components. We demonstrate the zero-shot sim-to-real transfer of our approach on a Kinova Gen3 manipulator picking task, for which the runtime monitor reliability model was trained using simulation-based data containing embodiment information of distance from the object being selected.
12:15-12:30, Paper SaBT10.4 Add to My Program
Drone As a Service in Logistics: A Review of Optimization and Control Techniques (I)
Porghoveh, Mojtaba Politecnico di Bari
Carli, Raffaele Politecnico di Bari
Dotoli, Mariagrazia Politecnico di Bari
Keywords: Autonomous Vehicle Navigation , Collaborative Robots in Manufacturing , Logistics
12:30-12:45, Paper SaBT10.5 Add to My Program
Adaptive Robust Controller for Handling Unknown Uncertainty of Robotic Manipulators (I)
Mohamed, Mohamed Mahmoud Abdelwahab University of Padova
Giacomuzzo, Giulio University of Padova
Dalla Libera, Alberto University of Padova
Carli, Ruggero University of Padova
Keywords: Robust/Adaptive Control , Model Learning for Control , Motion Control
Abstract: The ability to achieve precise and smooth trajectory tracking is crucial for ensuring the successful execution of various tasks involving robotic manipulators. State-of-the-art techniques require accurate mathematical models of the robot dynamics, and robustness to model uncertainties is achieved by relying on precise bounds on the model mismatch. In this paper, we propose a novel adaptive robust feedback linearization scheme able to compensate for model uncertainties without any a-priori knowledge on them, and we provide a theoretical proof of convergence under mild assumptions. We evaluate the method on a simulated RR robot. First, we consider a nominal model with known model mismatch, which allows us to compare our strategy with state-of-the-art uncertainty-aware methods. Second, we implement the proposed control law in combination with a learned model, for which uncertainty bounds are not available. Results show that our method leads to performance comparable to uncertainty-aware methods while requiring less prior knowledge.
12:45-13:00, Paper SaBT10.6 Add to My Program
An Automatic Sleep Staging Method Based on Spatio-Temporal JK-ViT Architecture (I)
An, Yu Peking University
Feng, Yikun School of Software and Microelectronics, Peking University, Beij
Li, Zhihong School of Integrated Circuits, Peking University, Beijing, China
Zhang, Xi College of Engineering, Peking University
Keywords: AI and Machine Learning in Healthcare , AI-Based Methods , Big-Data and Data Mining
Abstract: Sleep, a physiological process essential for human health, is characterized by distinct stages. The accurate identification of these stages is paramount for diagnosing sleep disorders and improving sleep quality. However, manual sleep staging is labor-intensive, which raises the need for automated sleep staging. Advances in machine learning, particularly deep learning, have shown promise in automating sleep stage classification, yet challenges persist in capturing the spatio-temporal dynamics of high-dimensional physiological data. Moreover, multi-source data from channels with different types are typically collected during the entire sleep process. It is essential to effectively utilize these data and capture the spatiotemporal correlations among different sources. Therefore, we propose a novel spatio-temporal sleep staging method based on a JK-ViT framework. In the proposed method, a Graph Encoder based on the Jumping Knowledge Network (JK-Net) structure is presented to capture the spatio-temporal dynamics. Leveraging the Vision-Transformer (ViT) framework, multisource data from channels of different types are fused and the attention layer captures the correlation between different sources. The effectiveness of method is validated using a private sleep PSG dataset, showcasing its potential to enhance the performance of sleep staging.

Digital Twin in Smart Construction II
Organizer: Zhao, Zhiheng The Hong Kong Polytechnic University
Organizer: Xu, Gangyan The Hong Kong Polytechnic University
Organizer: Zhong, Ray Y. The University of Hong Kong
Organizer: Pan, Wei The University of Hong Kong

11:30-11:45, Paper SaBT11.1 Add to My Program
Digital-Twins-As-A-Service in Construction Engineering
Zech, Philipp University of Innsbruck
Nardin, Claudio University of Innsbruck
Ristov, Sashko University of Innsbruck
Flora, Matthias University of Innsbruck
Breu, Ruth University of Innsbruck
Keywords: Automation in Construction , Cloud Computing For Automation , Building Automation
Abstract: Digital twins are powerful tools for real-time monitoring and control, and simulation and optimization of cyber-physical systems and processes, (cf. the physical twin). The Architecture, Engineering, Construction and Operation (AECO) domain is highly interested in exploiting digital twins, yet struggles with easily establishing these due to a lack of open, publicly accessible twinning platforms. Yet, with the introduc- tion of the Industry Foundation Classes, an open standard for model and data exchange, and the broad availability of public cloud infrastructures, the provisioning of a twinning platform for the AECO domain for the fully automated generation of digital twins of buildings (cf. the physical twin) is feasible. We report on a novel cloud-based platform for automated instantiation of digital twins. Our results demonstrate both the feasibility and relevance of our proposal to reduce the time and effort to implement and the cost to operate a digital twin atop managed cloud services.
11:45-12:00, Paper SaBT11.2 Add to My Program
Deep Reinforcement Learning Enabled Model for Green Last-Mile Delivery in MiC Construction (I)
Zhang, Wennan The University of Hong Kong
Yu, Chenglin The University of Hong Kong
Yu, Ying Zhejiang Normal University
Yin, Li The University of Hong Kong (HKU)
Zhong, Ray Y. The University of Hong Kong
Keywords: Automation in Construction , Machine learning , Sustainability and Green Automation
Abstract: With the rapid concerns of a sustainable environment, carbon emission reduction has become a major issue for climate change. Construction sector, as a key industry for carbon emission reduction, mainly consumes carbon through resource delivery. The existing models for green delivery simply integrate the carbon emission factor to evaluate the performance of the forward supply chain. This paper proposes a green last-mile delivery (GLD) model based on the milk-run strategy in MiC construction, which considers the vehicle limitation and empty loaded truck delivery. The objective is to devise a strategy that minimizes the carbon emission of forward and reverse flow of delivery. The implementation of the milk-run strategy aims to collect construction waste and return it to the MiC hub from construction sites using empty trucks. This model is solved by attention-based deep reinforcement learning based on the milk-run strategy. It can more accurately assess the carbon emissions during the last-mile delivery between the construction site and the MiC hub, which guides the construction and logistics companies to select a better distribution strategy under a low-carbon delivery. The results show that our proposed algorithm achieves solutions within 5% of the optimal easily and fast.
12:00-12:15, Paper SaBT11.3 Add to My Program
Digital Twin Enabled Construction Site Monitoring (CSM) Method with Edge-Cloud Collaboration (I)
Zhao, Shuxuan The University of Hongkong
Kang, Kai The University of Hong Kong
Xu, Chuqiao Shanghai Jiao Tong University
Guo, Xinyue The University of Hong Kong
Zhong, Ray Y. The University of Hong Kong
Keywords: Automation in Construction , AI-Based Methods , Machine learning
Abstract: In order to realize efficient construction site safety management, this paper proposes a digital twin enabled construction site monitoring (CSM) method with edge-cloud collaboration. Firstly, the high-fidelity virtual model including the building information model, physical model, behavior model and rule model is constructed to realize the accurate mapping of construction sites from physical space to virtual space and the causes analysis between behaviors and construction accidents. Secondly, the edge-cloud collaborative architecture is also designed to realize the reasonable allocation of computing tasks. In the edge-layer, the industrial CCD cameras and deep learning-based construction site detection methods are applied to realize the real-time images collection and detection on the construction sites. In the cloud layer, the cloud computing technology is used to realize the efficient data management, analysis, and model training. Finally, the experiment analysis is also implemented for the performance of the proposed deep learning-based construction site monitoring methods.
12:15-12:30, Paper SaBT11.4 Add to My Program
Digital Twin Enabled Collision Early Warning for Smart Site Safety System (SSSS) (I)
Zhao, Shuxuan The University of Hongkong
Yu, Chenglin The University of Hong Kong
Qu, Xinye The University of Hong Kong
Zhu, Zhengxu The University of Hong Kong
Lei, Junjie The University of Hong Kong
Zhong, Ray Y. The University of Hong Kong
Keywords: AI-Based Methods , Collision Avoidance , Computer Vision in Automation
Abstract: Construction industry is one of the most dangerous industry sectors as its high accident rates and fatality rates. Being struck by working construction machines is one major reason for accidents in construction sites. In this research, a digital twin-enabled collision warning system is designed to avoid collision and improve safety in construction industry. The system is composed of physical entity layer, virtual entity layer, digital data layer, service layer and connection. The digital data layer collects and analyzes virtual information collected from the physical layer. The virtual entity layer is responsible for constructing digital models with the same constraints, behaviors, and rules as the physical models. The service layer can provide on-site services such as on-site detection, collision warning, and motion status monitoring for site managers and workers. Besides, deep learning-based algorithms are also designed to achieve the classification, location, and key points detection of construction machines. The experiment results show that the proposed deep learning detection algorithms can achieve more than 90% detection performance, and the proposed framework can provide precise on-site collision early warning.
12:30-12:45, Paper SaBT11.5 Add to My Program
Spatial-Temporal Traceability and Relativity of Cyber Physical Internet in Modular Integrated Construction Logistics (I)
Zhao, Zhiheng The Hong Kong Polytechnic University
Zhou, Didi Nanjing University of Posts and Telecommunications, the Hong Kon
Liu, Hengzhi Nanjing Zhuling Technology Co., Ltd
Zhang, Mengdi The Hong Kong Polytechnic University
Huang, George Q. The University of Hong Kong
Keywords: Cyber-physical Production Systems and Industry 4.0 , Automation in Construction
Abstract: On the basis of Physical Internet (PI) which aims to build universal interconnection of logistics networks, the vision of Cyber Physical Internet (CPI) is to send and receive goods just like sending and receiving messages within chat groups with great traceability for all group members. The uncertainties, disruptions, and disturbances such city lockdown, factory shutdown, cross-border closures., etc. during the COVID-19, in global supply chain pose great challenges to end-to-end supply chain visibility, traceability and transparency. Spatial-temporal analytics is key to realizing traceability and exploring relativity in CPI. In this research, we first propose the contextual spatial-temporal reasoning with genetic self-learning method to identify the exact spatial-temporal status of the objects (what, where and when), and revisit classic operations research bin packing problem for modular integrated construction to explore and reveal the impact of spatial-temporal dynamicity and correlations on real-time decision-making.
12:45-13:00, Paper SaBT11.6 Add to My Program
Segmenting and Classifying Repetitive Construction Process Time Series Using Small Amount of Labeled Data
Zhang, Mingxi Technical University at Munich
Vogel-Heuser, Birgit Technical University Munich
Pantfoerder, Dorothea Technical University of Munich
KrÃ¼ger, Marius Technical University of Munich
Semel, Matthias BAUER Maschinen GmbH
Regler, Hans BAUER Maschinen GmbH
Vicaria, Alejandra Technical University of Munich
Keywords: Automation in Construction , Machine learning , Sensor Fusion
Abstract: Repetitive construction processes, as an essential element of construction industry, still rely intensively on manual execution and on-site decision-making. Within the proposal for integrating Cyber-Physical-System (CPS) in construction, time series analysis of sensor data has great potential to enhance construction project efficiency and support decision-making. However, owing to variable boundary conditions among construction projects, acquiring segmented and labeled training data for time series analysis models requires extensive human effort at the early stages of each construction project, with limited data reusability. We propose a Dynamic Time Warping-based (DTW) ensemble model for segmenting and assigning labels, which are predefined by experts as reference labels, for repetitive construction process through classification, requiring only small amount of labeled training data. The model is validated through a case study involving the Kelly Drilling process in two construction projects, achieving an average accuracy close to 90%. Minor errors occur only at subprocess transition points, in accordance with the error pattern in manual segmentation and labeling efforts. The proposed model addresses the challenge of the large human effort in acquisition of sufficient labeled segmented data in CPS in context construction under flexibility requirements.
SaBT12 Regular Session, Room T12 Add to My Program
Dynamics, Control, and Security in Multi-Agent Systems
Chair: Renda, Federico Khalifa University of Science and Technology
11:30-11:45, Paper SaBT12.1 Add to My Program
Dynamics and Control of Soft Robots with Implicit Strain Parametrization
Renda, Federico Khalifa University of Science and Technology
Mathew, Anup Teejo Khalifa University
Feliu, Daniel Khalifa University of Science and Technology
Keywords: Modeling, Control, and Learning for Soft Robots , Flexible Robotics , Dynamics
Abstract: Efficient modeling of soft robots for design optimization and control is an active area of research. When representing soft robots as an assembly of rods and rigid bodies, strain-based parametrization has proved to be able to reduce the required number of degrees of freedom drastically. However, this reduction ability strongly depends on the choice of strain basis employed to describe the system. In this paper, we proposed a new implicit strain parametrization, and we showed its use to represent the systemâ€™s configuration manifold with no more degrees of freedom than the number of actuators. Coupled with standard strain bases, this parametrization is applied to the dynamic simulation and control of soft robots employing a handful of generalized coordinates, drastically simplifying the control design problem. The approach is validated against a high-order model and exploited for shape (configuration space) and tip-pose (task-space) control of a complex tendon-driven soft robot.
11:45-12:00, Paper SaBT12.2 Add to My Program
An Investigation of Denial of Service Attacks on Autonomous Driving Software and Hardware in Operation
StÃ¼bler, Tillmann Akkodis Germany Solutions GmbH
Amodei, Andrea University of Cassino and Souther Lazio
Capriglione, Domenico University of Cassino and Southern Lazio
Tomasso, Giuseppe University of Cassino and Southern Lazio
Bonnotte, Nicolas Akkodis Germany Solutions GmbH
Mohammed, Shawan Akkodis Germany Solutions GmbH
Keywords: Motion and Path Planning , Motion Control , Control Architectures and Programming
Abstract: This research investigates the impact of Denial of Service (DoS) attacks, specifically Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) flood attacks, on Autonomous Driving (AD) systems, focusing on their control modules. Two experimental setups were created: the first involved an ICMP flood attack on a Raspberry Pi running an AD software stack, and the second examined the effects of single and double ICMP flood attacks on a Global Navigation Satellite System Real-Time Kinematic (GNSS-RTK) device for high-accuracy localization of an autonomous vehicle that is available on the market. The results indicate a moderate impact of DoS attacks on the AD stack, where the increase in median computation time was marginal, suggesting a degree of resilience to these types of attacks. In contrast, the GNSS device demonstrated significant vulnerability: during DoS attacks, the sample rate dropped drastically to approximately 50% and 5% of the nominal rate for single and double attacker configurations, respectively. Additionally, the longest observed time increments were in the range of seconds during the attacks. These results underscore the vulnerability of AD systems to DoS attacks and the critical need for robust cybersecurity measures. This work provides valuable insights into the design requirements of AD software stacks and highlights that external hardware and modules can be significant attack surfaces.
12:00-12:15, Paper SaBT12.3 Add to My Program
A Preliminary Study about Multi-Robot Task Allocation with Energy Constraints
Baccouche, Chaima University of Le Havre Normandy
Iben Ammar, Imen UniversitÃ© Le Havre Normandie
Lefebvre, Dimitri University LE HAVRE
Telmoudi, Achraf Jabeur ENSIT, UniversitÃ© De Tunis
Keywords: Autonomous Agents , Task Planning
Abstract: Fleets of mixed robots equipped with sensors offer a promising solution to enhance the monitoring of industrial and urban areas. However, the limited energy autonomy of these robots poses a challenge, requiring visits to charging stations as needed. In this paper a clustering methodology based on the k-means algorithm is employed to determine the optimal charging station locations and to ensure uninterrupted operation for mobile robots. Moreover, a novel approach to Multi-Robot Task Allocation (MRTA) is presented, integrating aspects of the multi Traveling Salesman Problem (mTSP) and the Electric Vehicle Routing Problem (E-VRP). By formulating this problem as a Mixed-Integer Linear Programming (MILP) model and employing standard solvers, we address these challenges. Preliminary simulation results demonstrate the practical effectiveness of our methodology in task assignment, planning, and energy resource management, within industrial environments.
12:15-12:30, Paper SaBT12.4 Add to My Program
Online Conflict-Free Scheduling of Fleets of Autonomous Mobile Robots
Popolizio, Francesco Chalmers University of Technology
Vinetti, Martina Chalmers University of Technology
Combrink, Alvin Chalmers University of Technology
Roselli, Sabino Francesco Chalmers University of Technology
Fanti, Maria Pia Politecnico Di Bari
Fabian, Martin Department of Electrical Engineering
Keywords: Planning, Scheduling and Coordination , Autonomous Vehicle Navigation , Agent-Based Systems
Abstract: This work presents a Fleet Manager for a fleet of Autonomous Mobile Robots (AMRs) that performs material handling tasks in a shared environment. The Fleet Manager assigns AMRs to newly released tasks, computes paths for them to travel to the taskâ€™s locations, and schedules their travel along the computed paths so that conflicts with other AMRs are avoided. The objective is for each AMR to complete its task as quickly as possible, to then be assigned a new task.

The Fleet Manager works online, assigning a released task to the AMR closest to the task's location, and then computing the path and schedule to fit in with the already assigned and executing AMRs. Conflicts occur when, in order to reach their targets, AMRs would have to simultaneously occupy the same space. Resolving this is done by appropriate scheduling, or by moving idle AMRs out of the way. For fleet management to be practicable, the computation time for assigning an AMR to a task and computing its path and schedule must be negligible compared to other system times.

Tests were conducted to evaluate the performance of the Fleet Manager on a number of benchmark problem instances, counting up to hundreds of AMRs. The results show that the presented Fleet Manager can handle these systems quickly enough to be practically useful in real industrial scenarios.

12:30-12:45, Paper SaBT12.5 Add to My Program
Study of a Condition Monitoring Method Based on the Concept of Complex Fuzzy Sets
Rodrigues de Oliveira, Wesley Aeronautics Institute of Technology (ITA)
Keywords: Diagnosis and Prognostics , Failure Detection and Recovery , AI-Based Methods
Abstract: This paper presents an application of the Complex Fuzzy Set (CFS) concept to the adaptation of an automated condition monitoring method (CMM). It is founded on the previous work from Ramot, which introduced the core aspects of the CFS and defined a related technique for measuring the similarity between two signals. The technique is adapted to the important problem of predicting the health of a system or machine. Some analyses based on synthetic signals are performed to theoretically support main aspects of the method. Other results focus on the use of synthetic signals from a robot model to monitor robot joint degradation, showing the potential of the CMM for different industrial applications that could benefit from a soft online condition monitoring approach.
12:45-13:00, Paper SaBT12.6 Add to My Program
A Multi-Robot System for the Study of Face-To-Face Interaction Dynamics
Tomaselli, Cinzia DIEEI University of Catania
Guastella, Dario Calogero UniversitÃ  Degli Studi Di Catania
Muscato, Giovanni Universita' Di Catania
Frasca, Mattia University of Catania
Gambuzza, Lucia Valentina DIEEI University of Catania
Keywords: Agent-Based Systems , Distributed Robot Systems , Networked Robots
Abstract: Face-to-face interactions are fundamental to the human social system, and, as such, they are a key ingredient in understanding how processes such as opinion dynamics, news and rumor diffusion, and epidemic spreading may occur. In this paper, we leverage the theoretical understanding provided by mathematical models based on complex networks of face-to-face interaction dynamics to propose a multi-robot system that facilitates experimental investigations of these dynamics in settings where the parameters are controllable. Specifically, we consider a team of Elisa-3 robots and implement a distributed and decentralized control law that enables the key mechanisms of interaction giving rise to face-to-face dynamics. We find that the multi-robot system reproduces the main features of the face-to-face dynamics such as long-tailed power-law distributions of contact durations and time intervals between successive contacts. Remarkably, these features prove to be robust, as they emerge in various experimental settings, as well as under challenging operating conditions of the system.
SaBVT1 Regular Session, Virtual T1 Add to My Program
[virtual] Planning, Scheduling and Coordination
11:30-11:45, Paper SaBVT1.1 Add to My Program
Long Short Term Memory Autoencoder-Aided Evolutionary Algorithm to Solve an Energy-Minimized Task Scheduling Problem (I)
Miao, Zhiwen Beijing University of Chemical Technology
Lin, Chengran Beijing University of Chemical Technology
Keywords: Planning, Scheduling and Coordination , AI-Based Methods , Task Planning
Abstract: This paper addresses a task scheduling problem with deadline constraints in a human-cyber-physical system, which contains three subproblems, i.e., allocating processer, and determining tasks' sequence and frequency. To efficiently find its energy-efficient solutions in a short time, an autoencoder-aided evolutionary algorithm is proposed. The main optimizer chosen for it is genetic programming. To extract the implicit relationship among three strongly-coupled subproblems, a novel long short term memory autoencoder is built. In it, a group of long short term memory units are used to learn major features of decision variables and generate a low-dimensional hidden representation of a solution. After that, some network-aided mutation operators are designed to generate offsprings in the resulting low-dimensional space with informative features. Numerical experiments comparing the proposed method with several competitive methods verify the effectiveness of the proposed method in finding high-quality schedules in a reasonable time.
11:45-12:00, Paper SaBVT1.2 Add to My Program
Low-Carbon Disassembly Sequence Planning with Improved Moth-Flame Optimizer by Considering Non-Homogeneous Information in Industry 5.0 (I)
Feng, Yixiong Zhejiang University
Cui, Kaiyue Zhejiang University
Hong, Zhaoxi Zhejiang University
Yan, Weiyu Zhejiang University
Song, Xiuju ZHEJIANG UNIVERSITY
Tan, Jianrong Zhejiang University
Keywords: Remanufacturing , Planning, Scheduling and Coordination , Optimization and Optimal Control
Abstract: Complex high-end equipment is the fundamental hardware of Industry 5.0. Low-carbon green disassembly for high-end equipment has prominent effects on Industry 5.0. However, low-carbon disassembly sequence planning (DSP) for complex high-end equipment is time-consuming and inefficient. Moreover, it is easy to generate non-homogeneous decision-making information due to cognitive uncertainty during disassembly evaluation, which makes it too difficult to determine the optimal solution. To address these issues, this work proposes a novel DSP method by integrating disassembly carbon benefit, improved Moth-Flame Optimizer (IMFO), and normalization of non-homogeneous information in this study. IMFO is designed to solve DSP. It adopts good-set theory, a nonlinear dynamic convergence factor, and an adaptive weight for greater efficiency in searching for feasible solutions. A 2-tuple is utilized as the uniform representation base to process non-homogeneous information. Finally, a case study for the CNC TGK46100 is provided to illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed method. Throughout the analysis, carbon benefit is increased by 1 to 2.83 times, and computing efficiency is increased by 68.57% and 61.27% over an advanced ant colony algorithm and genetic algorithm respectively.
12:00-12:15, Paper SaBVT1.3 Add to My Program
A Computationally Efficient Approach to Account for Stochastic Delays in Multi-Robot Task Allocation in a Proactive Manner
Chen, Shengqiang University of Southern California
Nguyen, Quan University of Southern California
Gupta, Satyandra K. University of Southern California
Keywords: Planning, Scheduling and Coordination , Autonomous Agents , Industrial and Service Robotics
Abstract: Delays play an important role in the overall performance of multi-robot missions. Delays can be handled in a reactive manner by replanning or can be handled proactively by selecting task allocations that are robust to delays. Mixed Integer Linear Programming (MILP) has emerged as a useful tool for solving multi-robot task allocation problems. The possibility of delays can be incorporated by sampling many different delay scenarios and generating an optional solution for each scenario. The solution that leads to the most robust performance is selected as the overall solution. Unfortunately, generating a large number of delay scenarios and computing the robustness of each solution by evaluating it using every sampled delay scenario is computationally very slow. This paper presents a method for speeding up computations by pruning solutions based on a similarity index. We evaluate the proposed approach using assembly and disinfection applications. We show that our approach leads to very good solutions with a modest computational effort.
12:15-12:30, Paper SaBVT1.4 Add to My Program
Preference Elicitation and Incorporation for Human-Robot Task Scheduling
Dhanaraj, Neel University of Southern California
Jeon, Minseok University of Southern California
Kang, Jeon Ho University of Southern California
Nikolaidis, Stefanos University of Southern California
Gupta, Satyandra K. University of Southern California
Keywords: Planning, Scheduling and Coordination , Human-Centered Automation , Human Factors and Human-in-the-Loop
Abstract: In this work, we address the challenge of incorporating human preferences into the task-scheduling process for human-robot teams. Humans have various individual preferences that can be influenced by context and situational information. Incorporating these preferences can lead to improved team performance. Our main contribution is a framework that helps elicit and incorporate preferences during task scheduling. We achieve this by proposing 1) a constraint programming method to generate a range of plans, 2) an intelligent approach for selecting and presenting task schedules based on task features, and 3) a preference incorporation method that uses large language models to convert preferences into soft constraints. Our results demonstrate that we can efficiently generate diverse plans for preference elicitation and incorporate them into the task-scheduling process. We evaluate our framework using an assembly-inspired case study and show how it can effectively incorporate complex and realistic preferences. Our implementation can be found at github.com/RROS-Lab/Human-Robot-Preference-Planning.
12:30-12:45, Paper SaBVT1.5 Add to My Program
A Large-Scale Charging Approach for Electric Vehicles Considering Multi-Station Collaboration and Task Optimization
Mao, Richard Xi'an Jiaotong University
Su, Ziru Xi'an Jiaotong University
Li, Defu Xi'an Jiaotong University
Zhao, Zexu Xi'an Jiaotong University
Keywords: Plug-in Electric Vehicles , Planning, Scheduling and Coordination , Cloud Computing For Automation
Abstract: The electric vehicle (EV) industry is growing rapidly in view of the increasing global awareness of environmental protection and the support of government policies. However, the stochastic nature of EV charging behavior poses the problem of peak load surge on the power grid, which seriously affects the stability of the grid system. This study aims to optimize the mass charging process of EVs to reduce the overall cost and improve user convenience. In this paper, we first establish a single-station large-scale sequential charging model to realize large-scale sequential charging within a charging station. Secondly, we develop a hybrid prediction model for rolling prediction of future charging loads at charging stations. Finally, we propose the LRDSAC algorithm that integrates the LLF-LD rule and discrete SAC, combines the prediction information and environmental information, and establishes a cloud-centered charging station recommendation model and a charging task optimization model for each charging station to achieve large-scale EV charging optimization considering multi-station collaboration and scheme recommendation. The research results show that the use of LRDSAC algorithm can eliminate the temporal coupling between charging tasks, greatly reduce the computational complexity, and realize charging station recommendation and optimized charging scheduling. By optimizing the charging end time, user fees can be reduced and charging station revenues can be increased while ensuring the charging volume remains unchanged, and the peak load of the grid can be reduced at the same time. We conducted a simulation analysis based on actual data in Shanghai, and the results verified the effectiveness of the method in this paper.
12:45-13:00, Paper SaBVT1.6 Add to My Program
Scheduling Reconfigurable Poly-Robots for Warehouse Transport Operations
Chaikovskaia, Mari IMT Atlantique
Gayon, Jean-Philippe LIMOS, INP Clermont Auvergne
Keywords: Planning, Scheduling and Coordination , Logistics , Industrial and Service Robotics
Abstract: We consider a warehouse where loads are transported by a fleet of elementary robots that can be aggregated to form poly-robots. The poly-robots can be reconfigured over time to adapt to load types such as boxes and pallets. Reconfigurable poly-robots offers several advantages: adaptability to load type and environment, failure tolerance, stability and maneuverability. We study the problem of scheduling such a fleet with the objective to minimize the time to execute all transportation tasks. We propose an integer linear programming formulation for the problems with or without reconfiguration. We show that reconfigurability can reduce significantly the execution time. We also establish that the special case with a single type of load can be solved in polynomial time. We end by showing how to extend the mathematical formulation to transportation times that depend on load type and configuration.

[virtual] Innovative Manufacturing and Automation
Chair: Gupta, Satyandra K. University of Southern California
11:30-11:45, Paper SaBVT2.1 Add to My Program
Contact Force Guidance Assembly towards Unknown-Shaped Dual Peg-In-Hole
Jin, Ninglong Shanghai Jiao Tong University
Du, Wei Shanghai Jiao Tong University
Wu, Jianhua Shanghai Jiao Tong University
Xiong, Zhenhua Shanghai Jiao Tong University
Keywords: Compliant Assembly , Assembly
Abstract: The automatic assembly of dual peg-in-hole often relies on the concrete CAD model, either explicitly or implicitly. However, especially in daily life, the shapes of pegs vary, and the robot cannot always obtain an accurate CAD model of the peg before performing the insertion task. Therefore, inspired by the force constraint during contact, we used contact force as the completion indicator of the assembly and proposed a novel two-stage assembly strategy for unknown-shaped dual peg-in-hole. Additionally, a variable remote compliance center method is employed to decouple the contact forces of two pegs and their adjustments. Three types of unidirectional movement modesâ€”exploration, compliance, retentionâ€”are utilized to guide the peg to contact with the hole under large initial offsets. The performance of the proposed assembly strategy was evaluated through a series of experiments using various shapes of pegs. The results show that our method effectively completes arbitrary mixed-shaped dual peg-in-hole task under large initial offsets in terms of orientation error (>20deg) and position error (>30mm) acorss all test cases.
11:45-12:00, Paper SaBVT2.2 Add to My Program
Estimation of External Force Acting on Underwater Robots
Lakshminarayanan, Srinivasan TUM
Duecker, Daniel Andre Technical University of Munich (TUM)
Sarabakha, Andriy Nanyang Technological University
Ganguly, Amartya Technical University of Munich
Takayama, Leila University of California, Santa Cruz
Haddadin, Sami Technical University of Munich
Keywords: Force and Tactile Sensing , Environment Monitoring and Management , Collision Avoidance
Abstract: In the context of robotics, accurately estimating external forces is essential. These estimations play a crucial role in collision detection, motion planning, robot control, disturbance compensation, environmental interactions, etc. Given the importance of external force estimation, We introduce a framework to estimate the forces acting on underwater robots. By leveraging dynamic models of the underwater remotely operated vehicle (ROV), our framework predicts and estimates forces based on velocity and acceleration data. We conducted real-world experiments on BlueROV2 underwater vehicle to test and verify the efficacy of our proposed framework. We determined that our framework can predict the external forces with an MAE of 0.8 N.
12:00-12:15, Paper SaBVT2.3 Add to My Program
Automated Plan Refinement for Improving Efficiency of Robotic Layup of Composite Sheets
Patel, Rutvik Rakeshbhai University of Southern California
Kanyuck, Alec University of Southern California
McNulty, Zachary University of Southern California
Yu, Zeren University of Michigan
Carlson, Lisa Boeing
Heng, Vann Boeing
Johnson, Brice Boeing
Gupta, Satyandra K. University of Southern California
Keywords: Intelligent and Flexible Manufacturing , Learning and Adaptive Systems , Reactive and Sensor-Based Planning
Abstract: The automation of composite sheet layup is essential to meet the increasing demand for composite materials in various industries. However, draping plans for the robotic layup of composite sheets are not robust. A plan that works well under a certain condition does not work well in a different condition. Changes in operating conditions due to either changes in material properties or working environment may lead a draping plan to exhibit suboptimal performance. In this paper, we present a comprehensive framework aimed at refining plans based on the observed execution performance. Our framework prioritizes the minimization of uncompacted regions while simultaneously improving time efficiency. To achieve this, we integrate human expertise with data-driven decision-making to refine expert-crafted plans for diverse production environments. We conduct experiments to validate the effectiveness of our approach, revealing significant reductions in the number of corrective paths required compared to initial expert-crafted plans. Through a combination of empirical data analysis, action-effectiveness modeling, and search-based refinement, our system achieves superior time efficiency in robotic layup. Experimental results demonstrate the efficacy of our approach in optimizing the layup process, thereby advancing the state-of-the-art in composite manufacturing automation.
12:15-12:30, Paper SaBVT2.4 Add to My Program
Co-Evolution DTs: Achieving Value-Added Cognitive Digital Twins across the Entire Lifecycle (I)
Tong, Xiaodong No.2999 Renmin Rord, Shanghai, China
Bao, Jinsong College of Mechanical Engineering, Donghua University
Tianyuan, Liu Donghua University
Keywords: Model Evolution (Systems and Software) , Cognitive Automation , Product Design, Development and Prototyping
Abstract: The comprehensive information generated from manufacturing activities throughout the lifecycle plays a vital role in enhancing cognitive intelligence, as it provides cognitive DT (CDT) with extensive historical and real-time status information, thereby facilitating value-driven and sustainable product lifecycle development. However, due to the highly complex interactions between modern industrial subsystems, integrating multiple relevant DTs from different lifecycle stages poses a challenging task. To address this, this paper presents the Co-Evolution DTs (CoEDTs)ï¼Œwhich providing a more comprehensive insight for future product development by constructing a parallel world that simulates the lifecycle. In the CoEDTs, we tackle the behavioral identification and structure of these evolving DTs throughout lifecycle through the following approaches. Initially, drawing inspiration from biological cytology, we have conceived a framework to establish the collective behavioral of multiple DTs. We then went on to further create CoEDTs, which support the co-evolutionary architecture and behavioral patterns of numerous DTs over the course of the product lifetime, by fusing digital threads and MBSE technology. Finally, the viability of the proposed CoEDTs framework is demonstrated through the development of a solid rocket engine.
12:30-12:45, Paper SaBVT2.5 Add to My Program
Measuring Object Rotation Via Visuo-Tactile Segmentation of Grasping Region
CastaÃ±o-AmorÃ³s, Julio University of Alicante
Gil, Pablo University of Alicante
Keywords: Perception for Grasping and Manipulation , Force and Tactile Sensing , Grasping
Abstract: When carrying out robotic manipulation tasks, objects occasionally fall as a result of the rotation caused by slippage. This can be prevented by obtaining tactile information that provides better knowledge on the physical properties of the grasping. In this paper, we estimate the rotation angle of a grasped object when slippage occurs. We implement a system made up of a neural network with which to segment the contact region and an algorithm with which to estimate the rotated angle of that region. This method is applied to DIGIT tactile sensors. Our system has additionally been trained and tested with our publicly available dataset which is, to the best of our knowledge, the first dataset related to tactile segmentation from non-synthetic images to appear in the literature, and with which we have attained results of 95% and 90% as regards Dice and IoU metrics in the worst scenario. Moreover, we have obtained a maximum error of â‰ˆ 3Âº when testing with objects not previously seen by our system in 45 different lifts. This, therefore, proved that our approach is able to detect the slippage movement, thus providing a possible reaction that will prevent the object from falling.
12:45-13:00, Paper SaBVT2.6 Add to My Program
Mining User Requirement Scenarios and Generating Design Solutions for Rehabilitation Aids Based on Large Language Models
Pan, Xinyu Donghua University
Gong, Jie Donghua University
Wen, Sijie Donghua University
Zhuang, Weibin Donghua University
Li, Xinyu Donghua University
Keywords: Product Design, Development and Prototyping
Abstract: The development of the rehabilitation aids industry for the disabled has been pivotal in recent years, particularly in the personalized design of lower limb rehabilitation aids. Facing challenges in meeting individualized demands in design practice and the information gap between medical professionals and users, we propose a design Knowledge Graph (KG) method based on the Function-Behavior-Structure (FBS) model. This approach utilizes open-source large language models (LLMs) and fine-tunes them with instruction data generated by self-instructions to improve the accuracy of user requirements mining. The method aims to enhance the personalization and innovation of rehabilitation aids design through the integration of KG and LLM, effectively narrowing the cognitive gap between service providers and users. The anticipated results of the study are expected to promote efficient innovation in rehabilitation aids design, better meeting the needs of the disabled community.

Intelligent Operation, Maintenance, and Scheduling in Complex Systems

14:00-14:15, Paper SaCT1.1 Add to My Program
Improved Discrete JAYA Algorithms for Hot Rolling Scheduling Considering Equipment Performance Degradation (I)
Zhong, Peitang Northeastern University
Zou, Kun Northeastern University
Zhao, Ziyan Northeastern University
Liu, Shixin Northeastern University
Keywords: Planning, Scheduling and Coordination , Manufacturing, Maintenance and Supply Chains
Abstract: Hot rolling is a typical industrial process with equipment performance degradation. Slabs to be rolled have specific equipment performance requirements and would cause different degrees of equipment performance degradation. Quantifying equipment performance to explore its impact on production scheduling has rarely been considered in existing work. In this paper, a new hot-rolling scheduling problem is tackled where the quantifying roller performance is considered. It aims to minimize the maximum completion time and the performance renewal cost. A mixed integer linear programming model is formulated for the problem. An improved discrete JAYA algorithm is proposed to effectively solve it. Experimental results show that the proposed algorithm performs well in solving the concerned problem, betters competitive peers, and shows great potential to be used in practice
14:15-14:30, Paper SaCT1.2 Add to My Program
Topology Mapping and Connectivity Detection for Autonomous Mobile Robot Systems (I)
Hou, Jingfu Northeastern University of China
Zhao, Ziyan Northeastern University
Liu, Shixin Northeastern University
Yang, Dawei KUKA China Robotic and Industrial Automation Division
Keywords: Agent-Based Systems , Industrial and Service Robotics , Formal Methods in Robotics and Automation
Abstract: Autonomous Mobile Robots (AMRs) are continuously improving the efficiency of logistics and material handling in smart manufacturing plants. However, it is still a very challenging task for AMR systems to create suitable and reliable maps with high robustness. AMR places stringent requirements on matching the accuracy of the map with the accuracy of the robot's task execution. In this paper, we propose a way to create maps for AMRs. A laser sensor is used to obtain a SLAM base map and construct a topology map on top of it. It can effectively cope with complex factory environments and support complex tasks. In addition, this paper proposes a topological map connectivity detection algorithm based on Tarjan's algorithm for detecting the correctness of AMR maps. The algorithm is improved based on the obtained algorithm. The results show that the improved algorithm can verify the correctness of AMR maps in a shorter time.
14:30-14:45, Paper SaCT1.3 Add to My Program
A Distributed Online Heuristic for a Large-Scale Workforce Task Assignment and Multi-Vehicle Routing Problem (I)
Deplano, Diego University of Cagliari
Seatzu, Carla University of Cagliari
Franceschelli, Mauro University of Cagliari, Italy
Keywords: Planning, Scheduling and Coordination , Task Planning , Human Performance Augmentation
Abstract: This paper presents a novel formulation for a workforce routing, task assignment, and scheduling problem with privacy constraints, drawing inspiration from multi-vehicle routing problems. We examine a real case study involving a large number of technicians tasked with refurbishing and repairing a large number of photo booth machines spread across a wide geographic area, spanning a country. We then introduce a novel heuristic distributed online optimization algorithm, based on gossiping, to: i) assign daily refurbishing and repair tasks to technicians; ii) plan optimal routes for each technician to execute the assigned tasks; iii) dynamically update task assignments and routes in real-time to accommodate delays and unforeseen impediments encountered by technicians (such as traffic jams). The objective is to maximize enterprise profit by effectively managing the workforce. The proposed method inherently safeguards the privacy of real-time geolocation data for the entire workforce, ensuring it remains undisclosed and inaccessible to the companyâ€™s ICT infrastructure. We provide a numerical simulation utilizing real data, supplied by DEDEM S.p.A., demonstrating the performance of the proposed heuristic in terms of expected net profit for the company.
14:45-15:00, Paper SaCT1.4 Add to My Program
Multi-Modal Double Row Layout Problem (I)
Zuo, Xingquan Beijing University of Posts and Telecommunications
Keywords: Intelligent and Flexible Manufacturing , Hybrid Strategy of Intelligent Manufacturing , Logistics
Abstract: Most existing studies on double row layout problem (DRLP) typically focus on designing a single optimal layout. However, there are typically multiple layouts with approximately optimal material handling cost for a DRLP. Identifying multiple global or local optimal layouts can provide layout designers with a wide range of options, which is of great significance for enhancing the maintainability, scalability, and customizability of the facility. In this paper, we study a Multi-modal Double Row Layout Problem (MDRLP). An approach combing a fast niching memetic algorithm and linear programming (FNMA-LP) is proposed for MDRLP to locate multiple global or local optimal layouts with a similar quality in a single execution run. Experiments show that our approach can find optimal solutions for small-scale problem instances and outperforms competing approaches on all problem instances.
15:00-15:15, Paper SaCT1.5 Add to My Program
Solving the Food-Energy-Water Nexus Problem Via Intelligent Optimization Algorithms (I)
Deng, Qi Tongji University
Fan, Zheng TongJi University
Li, Zhi TongJi University
Pan, Xinna Google
Kang, Qi Tongji University
Zhou, MengChu New Jersey Institute of Technology
Keywords: Environment Monitoring and Management , AI-Based Methods
Abstract: The application of evolutionary algorithms (EAs) to multi-objective optimization problems has been widespread. However, the EA research community has not paid much attention to large-scale multi-objective optimization problems arising from real-world applications. Especially, Foodâ€“Energyâ€“Water systems are intricately linked among food, energy and water that impact each other. They usually involve a huge number of decision variables and many conflicting objectives to be optimized. Solving their related optimization problems is essentially important to sustain the high-quality life of human beings. Their solution space size expands exponentially with the number of decision variables. Searching in such a vast space is challenging because of such large numbers of decision variables and objective functions. In recent years, a number of large-scale many-objectives optimization evolutionary algorithms have been proposed. In this paper, we solve a Foodâ€“Energyâ€“Water optimization problem by using the state-of-art intelligent optimization methods and compare their performance. Our results conclude that the algorithm based on an inverse model outperforms the others. This work should be highly useful for practitioners to select the most suitable method for their particular large-scale engineering optimization problems.
