Optimization of Scheduling for Parallel Die-Casting Production Systems (I)
Fan, Zhenghao Tsinghua University
Siu, Kwok On Tsinghua University
Keywords: Intelligent and Flexible Manufacturing , Planning, Scheduling and Coordination , Optimization and Optimal Control
Abstract: The die-casting process is crucial in industrial systems. Scheduling is one of the most vital and intricate operational challenges within die-casting production systems. In this abstract, we formulate the typical parallel die-casting scheduling problem considering the unique features of the die-casting workshop. An efficient solution algorithm is developed to solve the complex planning problem. The numerical results demonstrate the superiority of the proposed algorithm compared to the exact method.
SaCT2 Regular Session, Room T2 Add to My Program
Diagnosis and Fault Detection
14:00-14:15, Paper SaCT2.1 Add to My Program
Synthetic Data Generation with Reinforcement Learning for Fault Diagnosis of Rolling Bearings
Komatsu, Tenta Panasonic Industry Co., Ltd
Htun, Kyaw Myo Panasonic Industrial Devices Singapore Pte. Ltd
Liu, Zhiqi Panasonic Industry Co., Ltd
Usman, Muhammad Panasonic Industrial Devices Singapore Pte. Ltd
Juliano, Faye Panasonic Industrial Devices Singapore Pte. Ltd
Keywords: Diagnosis and Prognostics , Reinforcement , Manufacturing, Maintenance and Supply Chains
Abstract: Training deep neural networks on synthetic data is a promising method for solving the problems of data scarcity, label noise, and lack of data diversity. In the field of equipment maintenance automation, the training of diagnostic models on synthetic data has also been studied. These conventional studies assume that the simulation parameters of the equipment to be diagnosed can be accurately determined. However, it is not easy to accurately determine the simulation parameters of all equipment at actual equipment maintenance sites. In this study, a synthetic data generation framework using reinforcement learning is proposed. By defining the fault characteristic frequencies of a bearing as the state and the update amount of the simulation parameters as the action, it is possible to efficiently sample the simulation parameters without knowing the accurate values. The effectiveness of the proposed framework was verified using both open-access and in-house datasets. The results show that a deep neural network trained on a synthetic dataset, which was generated using the proposed framework, achieved higher diagnostic accuracy than one trained with randomly sampled simulation parameters. This research is the first to use reinforcement learning to generate bearing anomaly data.
14:15-14:30, Paper SaCT2.2 Add to My Program
Open-Set Fault Diagnosis Based on Prototype Learning with Dual Category-Classifier (I)
Ke, Shenqiang Huazhong University of Science and Technology
Gao, Liang Huazhong Univ. of Sci. & Tech
Li, Xinyu Huazhong University of Science and Technology
Gao, Yiping Huazhong University of Science and Technology
Keywords: Diagnosis and Prognostics , AI-Based Methods
Abstract: Fault diagnosis is one of the most essential parts of industry quality inspection. Recent years have seen great success in Deep-Learning (DL) based fault diagnosis methods. However, traditional supervised DL methods only aim at reducing the empirical risk but ignore the open space risk. Thus, when applied in the open-set scenario, these methods cannot recognize the unknown faults that have not occurred yet. To tackle this issue, this paper develops a novel dual category-classifier open-set framework to reduce both the empirical classification risk and the open space risk. In this framework, a reciprocal point and a prototypical point are deployed for each known category in the training phase. The reciprocal points are optimized by the extra-class space to enlarge the between-class distance, while the prototypical points are optimized to compress the within-class distance. Moreover, a margin constraint term is added for further restricting the distribution range. Finally, a novel-categories detector named Kernel Null Foley-Sammon Transform (KNFST) is adopted to reject the unknown fault modes. Computational experiments conducted on CWRU dataset, and a practical bearing dataset shows that the proposed method can successfully deal with the open-set fault diagnosis problem and achieve a remarkable improvement compared with most state-of-the-art methods.
14:30-14:45, Paper SaCT2.3 Add to My Program
An Early Fault Detection Framework for Wind Turbines Using Vibration Signals
Conradi Hoffmann, JosÃ© Luis Software/Hardware Integration Lab, Federal University of Santa C
MartÃ­nez de Lucena, Mateus Software/Hardware Integration Lab, Federal University of Santa C
Medeiros de Araujo, Gustavo Software/Hardware Integration Lab, Federal University of Santa C
FrÃ¶hlich, AntÃ´nio Augusto Software/Hardware Integration Lab, Federal University of Santa C
Keywords: Diagnosis and Prognostics , Failure Detection and Recovery , Machine learning
Abstract: Wind Turbines have been extensively adopted as primary renewable energy sources for over three decades. Many of these generators are now nearing the end of their expected operating time and have started to demand more intense maintenance. One alternative to extending their life is applying fault detection mechanisms to better schedule their maintenance. This work presents an early fault detection Framework based on Machine Learning applied to vibration data collected from Wind Turbines. The Framework includes mechanisms to filter less relevant data and decouple operational conditions from the signal. Feature extraction in the frequency domain and feature selection are applied to reduce data dimensionality and improve machine learning performance. Fault detection is achieved through a Deep Autoencoder model combined with a window-based reconstruction error analysis. The Framework is evaluated in a real case study, achieving promising results of detecting faults up to 76 days earlier than manual analysis.
14:45-15:00, Paper SaCT2.4 Add to My Program
Condition Monitoring with Incomplete Data: An Integrated Variational Autoencoder and Distance Metric Framework
Ahang, Maryam University of Victoria
Abbasi, Mostafa University of Victoria
Charter, Todd University of Victoria
Najjaran, Homayoun University of Victoria
Keywords: Diagnosis and Prognostics , Machine learning , Manufacturing, Maintenance and Supply Chains
Abstract: Condition monitoring of industrial systems is crucial for ensuring safety and maintenance planning, yet notable challenges arise in real-world settings due to the limited or non-existent availability of fault samples. This paper introduces an innovative solution to this problem by proposing a new method for fault detection and condition monitoring for unseen data. Adopting an approach inspired by zero-shot learning, our method can identify faults and assign a relative health index to various operational conditions. Typically, we have plenty of data on normal operations, some data on compromised conditions, and very few (if any) samples of severe faults. We use a variational autoencoder to capture the probabilistic distribution of previously seen and new unseen conditions. The health status is determined by comparing each sample's deviation from a normal operation reference distribution in the latent space. Faults are detected by establishing a threshold for the health indexes, allowing the model to identify severe, unseen faults with high accuracy, even amidst noise. We validate our approach using the run-to-failure IMS-bearing dataset and compare it with other methods. The health indexes generated by our model closely match the established descriptive model of bearing wear, attesting to the robustness and reliability of our method. These findings highlight the potential of our methodology in augmenting fault detection capabilities within industrial domains, thereby contributing to heightened safety protocols and optimized maintenance practices.
15:00-15:15, Paper SaCT2.5 Add to My Program
Benchmarking Sensor Modalities with Few-Shot Domain Adaptation for Cross-Domain Fault Diagnosis
Usman, Muhammad Panasonic Industrial Devices Singapore Pte. Ltd
Komatsu, Tenta Panasonic Industry Co., Ltd
Htun, Kyaw Myo Panasonic Industrial Devices Singapore Pte. Ltd
Liu, Zhiqi Panasonic Industry Co., Ltd
Beck, Aryel Panasonic Industrial Devices Singapore Pte. Ltd
Keywords: Diagnosis and Prognostics , Sensor Fusion , Manufacturing, Maintenance and Supply Chains
Abstract: Rotating machine fault diagnosis is challenging due to the inevitable differences in the operating conditions of source and target machines which significantly impact diagnostic performance. Therefore, it is essential to evaluate sensor modalities for intelligent fault diagnosis methods in various cross-domain cases to ensure robust performance. In this study, the performance of current and vibration modalities is benchmarked in cross-domain scenarios of variable machine operating conditions by employing one-dimensional convolutional neural network (1D CNN) model without any additional training on target data as a baseline. The impact of few-shot domain adaptation on their relative performance is also studied. Each sensor modality is analysed individually followed by an evaluation of their fusion. For few-shot domain adaptation in each case, a contrastive learning based framework is adopted and compared against traditional fine-tuning. The experimental results show that vibration is more effective than current for both baseline and domain adapted cross-domain fault diagnosis. The results also indicate that few-shot domain adaptation can alleviate the potential negative impact of fusion with underperforming modality and enable sensor fusion to have better cross-domain performance as compared to standalone modalities.
15:15-15:30, Paper SaCT2.6 Add to My Program
Data-Driven Approach for Satellite SADA System Health Monitoring with Limited Data (I)
Zhu, Xinting City University of Hong Kong
Li, Lishuai City University of Hong Kong
Mo, Yanfang The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology
Dong, Yining City University of Hong Kong
Shen, Xuejin Chengdu Atom Data Tech Co., Ltd
Chen, Xiaoyu Chengdu Atom Data Tech Co., Ltd
Qin, S. Joe Lingnan University
Keywords: Diagnosis and Prognostics , Machine learning , Big-Data and Data Mining
Abstract: The Solar Array Drive Assembly (SADA) system plays a critical role in managing satellite health by ensuring continuous power generation during orbital operations. Its operational dynamics are influenced by celestial phenomena involving the Sun, Earth, and Moon, particularly during eclipses. These dynamics produce complex, high-dimensional data patterns across different timescales and modes, necessitating advanced analytical approaches for effective health monitoring. This study focuses on comparing various data-driven methods to capture the multivariate, multiscale, and multimode nature of satellite operations, specifically for monitoring the SADA system. The methods employed include Principal Component Analysis (PCA), Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM), Dynamic Independent Component Analysis (DiCCA), and a scale-mode decoupled DiCCA framework. The latter is designed to uncover latent dynamics in orbital movements and satellite functionalities, using DiCCA as internal blocks for building prediction models. By comparing sensor observations with model predictions, the study tracks residuals to assess the SADA systemâ€™s health. Real-world datasets from a communication satellite SADA system validate the effectiveness of the scale-mode decoupled framework. This study not only enhances satellite anomaly detection capabilities but also advances understanding of SADA operations, contributing to more reliable satellite health management.
SaCT3 Special Session, Room T3 Add to My Program
Machine Learning for Optimization in Automation III
Chair: Lennartson, Bengt Chalmers University of Technology
Co-Chair: Fanti, Maria Pia Politecnico Di Bari
Organizer: Jia, Qing-Shan Tsinghua University
Organizer: Yan, Bing Rochester Institute of Technology
Organizer: Lennartson, Bengt Chalmers University of Technology
Organizer: Fanti, Maria Pia Politecnico Di Bari
14:00-14:15, Paper SaCT3.1 Add to My Program
A Multi-Layer Weather Classification-Based Regression Model for PV Power Prediction (I)
Bahij, Zeina Rochester Institute of Technology
Yan, Bing Rochester Institute of Technology
Keywords: Renewable Energy Sources , Sustainability and Green Automation
Abstract: Microgrid is a small-scale grid where generation is close to the demand allowing more penetration of renewables, like photovoltaic (PV). However, the intermittent nature of power generation in PV poses a significant challenge in microgrid operation, especially on days with highly variable weather conditions. In this work, a deep reinforcement Q-learning long short-term memory (QLSTM) model is developed to predict the operation strategy of a microgrid for the next day at a 15-minute time interval. To address the uncertainty of PV and demand, the previous three daysâ€™ PV and load data are added as inputs to the model since weather conditions on consecutive days depend on similar atmospheric conditions. Also, to address the effect of propagation of error in the long forecasting horizon with multiple steps, a moving window training method is implemented. The moving window will be shifted by 15 minutes at each step once the actual PV and load data are available till the end of the day. The model is tested in a microgrid consisting of combined cooling, heating and power, heat pump, PV, electrical energy storage, and heating and cooling energy storage system. Results show that our model outperforms gated recurrent unit, LSTM and Q-learning for testing data from different months. Also, it shows better performance than mixed integer linear programming that uses forecasted data, especially on a day with highly variable weather conditions.
14:15-14:30, Paper SaCT3.2 Add to My Program
A Tightened Formulation for Job Shop Scheduling with Mobile Robots (I)
Sahar, Najmus Rochester Institute of Technology
Basile, Anthony Rochester Institute of Technology
Yan, Bing Rochester Institute of Technology
Keywords: Planning, Scheduling and Coordination , Intelligent and Flexible Manufacturing , Collaborative Robots in Manufacturing
Abstract: In modern manufacturing, meeting the rising demand for customized products within tight deadlines poses significant challenges. Industry 4.0 offers opportunities to revolutionize manufacturing through automation, including adopting autonomous mobile robots. Integrating mobile robots into job shops introduces additional complexities, such as robot assignment and travel times, expanding the classical scheduling problem. In this paper, a mixed integer linear programming formulation is established to efficiently schedule mobile robots in smart job shops for on-time deliveries. It incorporates constraints on robot assignment and travel times alongside traditional machine and part-related constraints. To tackle the complexity of the problem, a systematic approach is employed to tighten the formulation, establishing linear relationships between operation and transportation sequence variables. Testing results demonstrate the effectiveness of the model and tightened constraints in achieving near-optimal solutions to meet on-time deliveries.
14:30-14:45, Paper SaCT3.3 Add to My Program
Accurately Predicting Probabilities of Safety-Critical Rare Events for Intelligent Systems (I)
Bai, Ruoxuan Tsinghua University
Yang, Jingxuan Tsinghua University
Gong, Weiduo Tsinghua University
Zhang, Yi Tsinghua University
Lu, Qiujing Tsinghua University
Feng, Shuo Tsinghua University
Keywords: Deep Learning in Robotics and Automation , Reinforcement , Agent-Based Systems
Abstract: Intelligent systems are increasingly integral to our daily lives, yet rare safety-critical events present significant latent threats to their practical deployment. Addressing this challenge hinges on accurately predicting the probability of safety-critical events occurring within a given time step from the current state, a metric we define as â€œcriticalityâ€. The complexity of predicting criticality arises from the extreme data imbalance caused by rare events in high dimensional variables associated with the rare events, a challenge we refer to as the curse of rarity. Existing methods tend to be either overly conservative or prone to overlooking safety-critical events, thus struggling to achieve both high precision and recall rates, which severely limits their applicability. This study endeavors to develop a criticality prediction model that excels in both precision and recall rates for evaluating the criticality of safety-critical autonomous systems. We propose a multi-stage learning framework designed to progressively densify the dataset, mitigating the curse of rarity across stages. To validate our approach, we evaluate it in two cases: lunar lander and bipedal walker scenarios. The results demonstrate that our method surpasses traditional approaches, providing a more accurate and dependable assessment of criticality in intelligent systems.
14:45-15:00, Paper SaCT3.4 Add to My Program
Non-Invasive Spatial Registration Using Customized Dental Bracket and Improved Genetic Algorithms
Ye, Angen Institute of Automationï¼ŒChinese Academy of Sciences
Song, Yujia Institute of Automation, Chinese Academy of Sciences
Su, JiangFeng Institute of Automation Chinese Academy of Sciences
Zhang, Dapeng Institute of Automation, Chinese Academy of Sciences
Keywords: Brain-Machine Interfaces , Physically Assistive Devices , AI and Machine Learning in Healthcare
Abstract: In order to implant the flexible electrodes into the brain safely, the titanium screws are driven into the skull to register the patientâ€™s physical space with imaging spaces obtained from CT. The operation may cause bleeding risk, and the distribution of screws depends on the doctorâ€™s subjective experience. This paper proposes a non-invasive registration approach based on a customized dental bracket, a series of registration balls are arranged on the bracket. Additionally, an improved genetic algorithm (IGA) is introduced to select the optimal registration balls automatically according to the implantation target position, which can promote the registration accuracy effectively. Experimental results show that the proposed method can achieve a registration error within 0.36mm without the screws implantation, which can meet the requirements for flexible electrode implantation. Additionally, compared to manual selection screws, the target registration errors are reduced by 61.3%, and the computing time of IGA is within 0.2 seconds.
15:00-15:15, Paper SaCT3.5 Add to My Program
Deep Reinforcement Learning-Based Symbolic Regression for PDE Discovery Using Spatio-Temporal Rewards (I)
Wang, Xizhe Tsinghua University
Zhao, Hongbo Princeton University
Zhao, Qianchuan Tsinghua University
Jiang, Benben Tsinghua University
Keywords: AI-Based Methods , Machine learning , Power and Energy Systems automation
Abstract: The discovery of partial differential equations (PDEs) directly from data has significant implications for automation and manufacturing fields. This approach leverages advanced computational techniques and data-driven methodologies to identify the underlying mathematical models that govern the physical processes in various systems. In this article, a deep symbolic regression framework is developed for PDE discovery which is enhanced by reinforcement learning with spatio-temporal rewards. Within this framework, a dense encoder-decoder network is utilized to adeptly extract the information of temporal dynamics related to PDEs from the data, and a refined reinforcement learning reward shaping technique is further introduced that incorporates the extracted dynamics, specifically designed for PDE symbolic regression tasks. An example of Cahn-Hilliard equation, which is widely used to describe the phase separation process in multi-component mixture systems, is used to validate the effectiveness of the proposed approach. The experimental results show that the proposed deep symbolic regression approach outperforms the baselines in identifying PDEs, achieving higher accuracy with less data. Additionally, we provide a thorough analysis on how adjustable parameters affect the PDE discovery performance, further verifying the effectiveness of the proposed approach.
15:15-15:30, Paper SaCT3.6 Add to My Program
Double Deep Q-Learning Based on Personalized Thermal Comfort Model for HVAC Optimization (I)
Zhou, Hanchen Tsinghua University
Wang, Di Xi'an Jiaotong University
Xu, Zhanbo Xi'an Jiaotong University
Jia, Qing-Shan Tsinghua University
Keywords: Building Automation , Modelling, Simulation and Validation of Cyber-physical Energy Systems , Reinforcement
Abstract: The operation of Heating, Ventilation and AirConditioning (HVAC) systems in buildings has huge energy saving potential and therefore HVAC optimization can greatly reduce carbon emission. How to balance energy cost and thermal comfort of occupants still needs to be researched. The most common approach is to use a static range of air temperature or PMV(Predicted Mean Vote) to describe thermal sensation and regard it as constraints for energy optimization problem. However, further research illustrates that people may perceive differently in the same environment, and its effect on HVAC control has not been analysed. To address this problem, the personalized thermal comfort is considered to further improve energy efffciency and satisfaction of occupants. Speciffcally, Double Deep Q-learning based on Personalized Thermal Comfort model for HVAC optimization(called PTCDDQ framework) is proposed in this work. First, metabolic rate is used to describe thermal difference, and it is estimated by genetic algorithm using actual votes of occupants. Second, PMV thermal models with different metabolic rates are combined with HVAC models simulated by Energyplus to formulate the optimization problem. Then Double Deep Q-learning algorithm is applied to solve the problem. Third, three kinds of people, coldintolerant, neutral and hot-intolerant are deffned to compare the performance of PTCDDQ and traditional control methods. Case study results show that PTCDDQ framework can enhance energy efficiency and thermal satisfaction at the same time.

Autonomous Systems for Agriculture and Horticulture III
Chair: Duke, Mike Waikato University
Co-Chair: McGuinness, Benjamin John University of Waikato
Organizer: Anisi, David A. NMBU
Organizer: Lim, Shen Hin University of Waikato
Organizer: Duke, Mike Waikato University

14:00-14:15, Paper SaCT4.1 Add to My Program
Non-Destructive Biomass Estimation Based on 3D Reconstruction from a Handheld Camera (I)
Singh, Jaspreet University of Lincoln
Cielniak, Grzegorz University of Lincoln
Keywords: Agricultural Automation
Abstract: With the recent advancements in sensing technology and machine learning, it has become possible to develop agricultural technologies that can keep pace with the shrinking agriculture workforce and growing population needs. Above-ground biomass (AGB) is a key trait for crop growth monitoring, crop breeding and yield prediction for agricultural scientists as well as for farmers. It is essential to develop an accurate non-destructive method because the destructive measurement of AGB is manual, time-consuming and expensive. In this paper, we propose and validate a new pipeline based on the latest low-cost technologies to accurately acquire 3D point clouds of the crop plots using a consumer camera and an off-the-shelf structure-from-motion reconstruction algorithm. Unlike the previous methods, the proposed non-destructive AGB pipeline does not rely on large amount of training data and high-cost field robots to capture the 3D data. The proposed pipeline for estimating AGB consists of three steps: i) 3D reconstruction of the crop plot, ii) estimating the volume of the crop plot, and iii) estimating the biomass from the volume. The experimental results showed a strong correlation between the plot volume and biomass with the minimum error in the final estimated biomass as compared to the recorded ground truth biomass.
14:15-14:30, Paper SaCT4.2 Add to My Program
How about Them Apples: 3D Pose and Cluster Estimation of Apple Fruitlets in a Commercial Orchard (I)
Qureshi, Ans University of Auckland
Smith, David Anthony James University of Auckland
Gee, Trevor The University of Auckland
Ahn, Ho Seok The University of Auckland, Auckland
McGuinness, Benjamin John University of Waikato
Downes, Catherine University of Waikato
Jangali, Rahul The University of Waikato
Black, Kale Black Box Technologies LTD
Lim, Shen Hin University of Waikato
Duke, Mike Waikato University
MacDonald, Bruce University of Auckland
Williams, Henry University of Auckland
Keywords: Agricultural Automation
Abstract: Aotearoaâ€™s apple industry struggles to maintain the skilled workforce required for fruitlet thinning each year.Skilled labourers play a pivotal role in managing crop loads by precisely thinning fruitlets to a desired number to achieve the desired spacing for high-quality apple growth. This complex task requires accurate mapping of the fruitlets along each branch. This paper presents a novel vision system capable of mapping the orientation and clustering information of apple fruitlets as a human expert does. The vision system has been validated against data collected from a real-world commercial apple orchard. The results show an improved counting accuracy of 83.97% on prior implementations, an orientation estimate accuracy of 88.1%, and a clustering accuracy of 94.3%. Future work will utilise this information to determine which fruitlets to remove and then robotically thin them from the canopy.
14:30-14:45, Paper SaCT4.3 Add to My Program
Mass Estimation of Soft Fruit Via Oscillatory Plant Dynamics (I)
Wagner, Nikolaus University of Lincoln
Cielniak, Grzegorz University of Lincoln
Keywords: Agricultural Automation , Computer Vision in Automation , Sustainable Production and Service Automation
Abstract: Yield forecasting is an essential task in modern agriculture, as it enables farmers and food economists to manage crop and its distribution precisely and effectively. Traditionally, most methods for yield forecasting are based on historical data and yield estimates from manually collected samples. More modern approaches often rely on computer vision-based fruit counting algorithms, which do not take individual crop weights into account.

In this paper, we propose a novel, non-destructive method to estimate the mass of individual pieces of fruit by exploiting the dynamic properties of plants. By observing short-term oscillatory plant motion through RGB-D video data, we formulate an approach for mass estimation based on determining the parameters of a damped harmonic oscillator model.

We test the proposed algorithm by collecting a dataset of around 300 video samples of strawberries on a real strawberry farm and apply our method. With a semi-automated toolchain, capable of inferring the key parameters from video data and calculating the mass of individual berries from those, we were able to estimate the mass of all berries in our dataset with a median error of 1.16g, outperforming a baseline utilising vision-based volume estimation to infer the mass. These insights hold valuable improvements for the development of yield forecasting systems and selective harvesters, which help to address the sustainability of food production and labour shortages.

14:45-15:00, Paper SaCT4.4 Add to My Program
Multi-Objective Dispatching for Shared Harvesters (I)
Wang, Yi-Jia China Agricultural University
Keywords: Agricultural Automation , Planning, Scheduling and Coordination , Task Planning
Abstract: Agricultural production is seasonal and labor-intensive, particularly harvesting. The crop of the same variety in the same city matures during the same period or even on the same day. Compared with harvesting by hand, harvesting by harvesters takes less time and reduces post-harvest losses. However, the price of harvesters is considerably high, and most farmers in developing countries can not afford it. Thus, the introduction of shared harvesters is considered an effective method of providing on-demand harvesting services for farmers. Farmers submit the acreage of farmlands, the crop, and the required harvesting time. The shared agricultural machinery companies (SAMC) would dispatch responsive harvesters assigned with operators for harvesting based on these demands. The charges of such services mainly depend on the acreage of farmlands, and each driver's revenue earns from such charges of those orders assigned to him. While the concept of shared harvester has the potential to reduce farmers' workload and costs, it is challenging to dispatch harvesters considering the preferences of farmers, drivers and the SAMCs. First, crops should be harvested at the earliest possible time as the harvesting time impacts yield seriously. Farmers prefer that their farmlands could be served as soon as possible. However, the number of shared harvesters is limited and far fewer than that of farmlands. The operators could not provide on-demand harvesting services for all farmers at the same time. Thus, the dispatching plan should consider reducing the ending time of harvesting each farmland. Second, drivers' revenue is from the charges, and drivers wish to earn higher revenue. However, the total number of charges and the number of drivers are fixed by the orders. Thus, the gap between the d
15:00-15:15, Paper SaCT4.5 Add to My Program
The Barracuda: A Novel Cutting Mechanism for Pruning Canes Wrapped Around Wires (I)
Williams, Henry University of Auckland
Harvey, Scott University of Waikato
McGuinness, Benjamin John University of Waikato
Smith, David Anthony James University of Auckland
Lim, Shen Hin University of Waikato
Duke, Mike Waikato University
Keywords: Agricultural Automation
Abstract: This paper presents the design and evaluation of the Barracuda, a novel pruning tool for robotic automation to cut grapevine canes tightly wrapped around wires. The Barracuda's anvil has specially designed grooves that allow the wire to move passively out of the way while the blade completes the cut on the cane. The intention is to enable a robotic cane pruning platform to prune canes on wires without precise positioning of the device or manipulation of the wires.The device was extensively tested in real-world commercial vineyards to evaluate how effectively it can produce clean cuts suitable for pruning. Cutting performance showed a successful cut rate of 94.5% with negligible wire damage on over 300 cuts. Evaluations on the robotic platform showed it could successfully prune 71.1% of canes while utilising this design.
15:15-15:30, Paper SaCT4.6 Add to My Program
Lightweight and Efficient Attention-Based CNN Models for In-Field Strawberry Instance Segmentation (I)
Zhao, Ziang Cardiff University
Hicks, Yulia Cardiff University, Cardiff School of Engineering
Sun, Xianfang Cardiff University
McGuinness, Benjamin John University of Waikato
Lim, Shen Hin University of Waikato
Keywords: Agricultural Automation , AI-Based Methods , Computer Vision for Manufacturing
Abstract: Accurately segmenting strawberries within real-world production settings not only helps the development of automated harvesting robots but also allows for precise calculation of the number and size of strawberries, providing accurate yield information for agricultural planning and resource optimization. This paper proposes lightweight and efficient CNN models specifically designed for strawberry instance segmentation, consisting of an efficient self-attention-based backbone, a feature pyramid network (FPN), and a decoder with an instance branch and a mask branch. The proposed models surpass the original and simplified Mask R-CNN with significant 21.46 and 22.97 AP gains respectively, with the Base backbone achieving the highest AP of 70.22. Additionally, our models demonstrate efficiency by requiring much fewer parameters (17.42M) and floating-point operations (78.3G) compared to Mask R-CNN (35.08M/877.4G), making them suitable for deployment on devices with limited computational resources.

Automated Sample Processing
Chair: Fleischer, Heidi University of Rostock
Co-Chair: Bucolo, Maide University of Catania
14:00-14:15, Paper SaCT5.1 Add to My Program
Automated Sample Transportation and Handling for Determination of Trace Metals in Cell Growth Media Using ICP-MS
Fleischer, Heidi University of Rostock
Tlili, Mohamed Ali University of Rostock
Roddelkopf, Thomas University Rostock
Thurow, Kerstin University Rostock
Keywords: Automation in Life Science: Biotechnology, Pharmaceutical and Health Care , Robotics and Automation in Life Sciences
Abstract: The demand for automated systems is high in biological element-oriented measurements. In contrast to highly automated bioscreening systems, analytical measurements are often not completely automated due to the high complexity of the sample preparation and measurement processes. Cell culture media for cell nutrition and growing strongly differ in their composition depending on the cells to be cultivated. Metals are important components of cell culture media in a wide concentration range, and they can significantly influence the cell growing in both directionsâ€”supporting or inhibiting. Sources of metal introduction and variation in the media are the raw material preparation as well as leaching of metals from vessels, containers, and tools. Therefore, the determination and monitoring of trace metals in source materials for cell growth media is of great importance. Measurements using ICP-MS provide a high sensitivity, low detection limits, and an effective reduction of interfering signals. In this study, an automated sample transportation and handling system was integrated with a measurement system using inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) to determine heavy metals in cell growth media. The automated measurement system was validated by the determination of the repeatability, recovery rate, within-laboratory precision, measurement precision as well as the analytical and methodological limits of detection and quantification (LOD and LOQ). The robotic system was tested with blank samples and the results showed only a low contamination risk caused by the metal construction parts. The automated system can be safely used even in trace metal determination. Concentrations of trace metals of commercial cell culture media from various vendors were determined.
14:15-14:30, Paper SaCT5.2 Add to My Program
Accelerating Laboratory Automation through Robot Skill Learning for Sample Scraping
Pizzuto, Gabriella University of Liverpool
Wang, Hetong University of Liverpool
Fakhruldeen, Hatem University of Liverpool
Peng, Bei University of Liverpool
Luck, Kevin Sebastian Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam
Cooper, Andrew Ian University of Liverpool
Keywords: Automation in Life Science: Biotechnology, Pharmaceutical and Health Care , Robotics and Automation in Life Sciences
Abstract: The use of laboratory robotics for autonomous experiments offers an attractive route to alleviate scientists from tedious tasks while accelerating material discovery for topical issues such as climate change and pharmaceuticals. While some experimental workflows can already benefit from automation, sample preparation is still carried out manually due to the high level of motor function and dexterity required when dealing with different tools, chemicals, and glassware. A fundamental workflow in chemical fields is crystallisation, where one application is polymorph screening, i.e., obtaining a three dimensional molecular structure from a crystal. For this process, it is of utmost importance to recover as much of the sample as possible since synthesising molecules is both costly in time and money. To this aim, chemists scrape vials to retrieve sample contents prior to imaging plate transfer. Automating this process is challenging as it goes beyond robotic insertion tasks due to a fundamental requirement of having to execute fine- granular movements within a constrained environment (sample vial). Motivated by how human chemists carry out this process of scraping powder from vials, our work proposes a model-free reinforcement learning method for learning a scraping policy, leading to a fully autonomous sample scraping procedure. We first create a scenario-specific simulation environment with a Panda Franka Emika robot using a laboratory scraper that is inserted into a simulated vial, to demonstrate how a scraping policy can be learned successfully in simulation. We then train and evaluate our method on a real robotic manipulator in laboratory settings, and show that our method can autonomously scrape powder across various setups
14:30-14:45, Paper SaCT5.3 Add to My Program
Robot Based Automated Sample Processing
Tlili, Mohamed Ali University of Rostock
Thurow, Kerstin University Rostock
Roddelkopf, Thomas University Rostock
Keywords: Robotics and Automation in Life Sciences
Abstract: The level of automation in life science laboratories is still quite low today. With the development of the microtiter plate as a standard format for biological applications, numerous automation solutions have been developed. Classic analytical or diagnostic laboratories generally cannot use these developments because they process individual samples and processing in microtiter plate format is not possible. Automation systems for these applications must therefore be complex systems with central robots as transport entities. The automation of all substeps also requires the development and integration of special devices to realize the full required functionality. A corresponding system was developed for the sample preparation of human samples that enables the parallel processing of up to six samples per run. The developed system enables the opening and closing of vessels, the filtration of larger sample volumes and the dosing of individual volumes in the range from 30 to 90 ml.
14:45-15:00, Paper SaCT5.4 Add to My Program
Flexible Automation System for Parameter Screening and Small Scale Protein Purification Applied to Colostrum Samples
Bach, Anna University of Rostock
Palent, Julia InnerstÃ¤dtisches Gymnasium
Zastrow, Tim InnerstÃ¤dtisches Gymnasium
Kupke, Christa InnerstÃ¤dtisches Gymnasium
Roddelkopf, Thomas University Rostock
Tlili, Mohamed Ali University of Rostock
Fleischer, Heidi University of Rostock
Thurow, Kerstin University Rostock
Keywords: Automation in Life Science: Biotechnology, Pharmaceutical and Health Care , Robotics and Automation in Life Sciences , Sustainability and Green Automation
Abstract: The pharmaceutical industry has seen a significant growth in monoclonal antibodies due to their highly specific mechanisms of action, which enable the targeted treatment of various diseases. Colostrum, the premature milk of mammals, is a natural source of antibodies that may be used to support the immune system of humans. However, high antibody concentrations only occur within a few days, making it crucial to differentiate between premature and mature milk. In this paper, an efficient approach for quantifying the antibody content of colostrum powder is presented. A liquid-handling system is used to automate the process. By integrating external devices such as a centrifuge and connecting the liquid handling system to the measuring device using a robotic arm, it is possible to automate the entire laboratory process. The efficiency of the system is demonstrated by an annual saving of â‚¬82.000 compared to the manual process. Miniaturized chromatographic columns in a microplate format are used to purify the antibody content of colostrum powder. The purification process was optimized through an extensive parameter screening, resulting in an optimized method with a high yield and precision of 91.2% and an RSD of 7.43%. The method's environmental friendliness is proven through a sustainability assessment.
15:00-15:15, Paper SaCT5.5 Add to My Program
Automatic Label-Free Classification of Viable Cell On-A-Chip
Cutuli, Emanuela University of Catania
Stella, Giovanna University of Catania
Migliore, Josephine University of Catania
Valenti, Giulia University of Catania
Guarino, Francesca University of Catania
Sanalitro, Dario University of Catania
Bucolo, Maide University of Catania
Keywords: Automation in Life Science: Biotechnology, Pharmaceutical and Health Care , Automation at Micro-Nano Scales
Abstract: Cell viability assessment is significantly important in many applications in the field of biochemical systems analysis and medical diagnosis. In this work, a label-free cell viability characterization which leverages hydro-dynamical stimulation is proposed. As a first proof of concept, the collective behaviour of healthy and unhealthy stimulated eukaryotic yeast cells of emph{Saccharomyces cerevisiae}, subjected to an oscillatory input flow within a microchannel, has been studied. The goal is to demonstrate the contrasting behavior of healthy cells compared to the same cells undergoing an apoptosis process. With the aim of developing integrated Lab-on-a-Chip and towards the challenge of real-time analyses, a novel Time-Slot DPIV-based implementation is proposed for the time and frequency evaluation of the acquired data in predefined time windows. The proposed algorithm condenses the setting, acquisition, and analysis phases into a unified framework. Thus, the data collection, the results visualization, and the entire analysis process have been shortened. Experimental results demonstrate the validity of the approach in speeding up the data collection, analysis, and displaying phases without compromising the methodology validity.
15:15-15:30, Paper SaCT5.6 Add to My Program
Vaulting Detection with the Multi-Model Unscented Kalman Filter
Macht, Jesse Peter University of Toronto
Taylor, Joshua New Jersey Institute of Technology
Azhari, Fae University of Toronto
Keywords: Rehabilitation , Clinical and Operational Decision Support , Prosthetics and Exoskeletons
Abstract: A method for automatically detecting vaulting gait is presented. Two gait models are parameterized based on data from humans, representing a normal gait and a vaulting gait. Structural observability analysis is performed taking into account measurements from a wearable sensor package. A multi-model Unscented Kalman Filter is applied to sensor data from live trials to automatically detect the gait mode.
